item.title: Rust at scale üìà, how Cursor shipped Composer üå±, Karpathy on Claude Code üß†
item.description:
WhatsApp added a layer of security for three billion users by replacing 160,000 lines of C++ with 90,000 lines of Rust. ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

 TLDR Dev 2026-01-28

Report: 96% of devs don't fully trust AI code (Sponsor)

AI is accelerating code generation, but it's creating a bottleneck in the verification phase. Based on a survey of 1,100+ developers, Sonar's newest State of Code report analyzes the impact of generative AI on software engineering workflows and how developers are adapting to address it.

Findings include: 

  • 96% of developers don't fully trust that AI-generated code is functionally correct yet only 48% always check it before committing
  • 61% agree that AI often produces code that looks correct but isn't reliable
  • 24% of a developer's work week is spent on toil work

Download now

üßë‚Äçüíª

Articles & Tutorials

Rust at Scale: An Added Layer of Security for WhatsApp (5 minute read)

WhatsApp added a layer of security for three billion users by replacing 160,000 lines of C++ with 90,000 lines of Rust. This global deployment, called Kaleidoscope, mitigates memory safety vulnerabilities in media processing. The cross-platform migration improved performance and runtime memory usage across Android, iOS, and web clients.
How Cursor Shipped its Coding Agent to Production (12 minute read)

Cursor's team shipped Composer, a coding agent that completes most tasks in under 30 seconds, by solving three gnarly engineering problems: the ‚Äúdiff problem‚Äù (models aren't great at making clean code edits, so they trained specifically on edit trajectories and search-replace operations), compounded latency (each step in the agent loop adds delay, so they used MoE architecture, speculative decoding with draft models, and aggressive context compaction to stay fast), and sandboxing at scale (they built custom VM infrastructure to spin up thousands of isolated execution environments without the startup time becoming a bottleneck).
üß†

Opinions & Advice

A few random notes from Claude coding quite a bit last few weeks (5 minute read)

Andrej Karpathy has had a rapid shift in their coding workflow, moving from 80% manual to 80% LLM agent-driven programming within weeks. While LLMs boost productivity, stamina, and project scope by handling code generation, they still produce subtle conceptual errors, overcomplicate code, and necessitate close human oversight within an IDE. Despite these flaws, the LLM-assisted workflow makes coding more enjoyable by removing drudgery and expanding engineering capabilities.
We're All Beginners Again (2 minute read)

Early AI adoption mirrors the early Python ecosystem, restoring play to programming. Since no definitive advanced standards exist, developers should embrace experimentation over legacy maintenance.
üöÄ

Launches & Tools

üí£ v0 by Vercel is vibe coding without the security time bomb (Sponsor)

Most AI coding tools optimize for speed and novelty, which risks leaked credentials and company data. Need something that can actually go to prod? v0 is built on the same infrastructure that's handled hundreds of millions of deployments and blocked hundreds of billions of threats in the last year. Start here
Open Coding Agents: Fast, accessible coding agents that adapt to any repo (11 minute read)

Ai2 has launched Open Coding Agents, an initiative to address the limitations of existing closed and expensive coding agent systems. They are releasing SERA (Soft-verified Efficient Repository Agents), a family of strong open coding models and an accessible training method. This method significantly reduces the cost and complexity of fine-tuning powerful coding agents on private codebases, allowing small teams to achieve state-of-the-art performance. Ultimately, Ai2 aims to democratize access to agentic coding, making it more reproducible and adaptable for researchers and developers worldwide.
Prism (Website)

OpenAI has launched Prism, a free, AI-native workspace to accelerate science writing and collaboration for researchers. Powered by GPT-5.2, this cloud-based, LaTeX-native platform integrates drafting, revision, collaboration, and preparation for publication into a single workflow.
üéÅ

Miscellaneous

From Prompts to Clicks: Shipping MCP Apps in Production (17 minute read)

Monday.com has successfully implemented MCP Apps, an extension to the Model Context Protocol, allowing AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude to return interactive UI components directly within chat conversations. This approach enables users to "ask, see, and act" on information without leaving the chat, but it's important to only show UI selectively where seeing beats reading.
AGENTS.md outperforms skills in our agent evals (9 minute read)

AI coding agents struggle with outdated framework knowledge, leading to incorrect code generation. Researchers from Vercel evaluated two approaches for providing current Next.js API documentation: "skills" (on-demand knowledge packages) and "AGENTS.md" (a persistent, embedded markdown file). Surprisingly, a compressed 8KB docs index embedded directly in AGENTS.md achieved a perfect 100% pass rate in their evals, outperforming skills, which only reached 79% even with explicit triggering instructions.
‚ö°

Quick Links

Doing the thing is doing the thing (2 minute read)

Only actual execution, even if imperfect, constitutes "doing the thing," as opposed to contemplation, planning, or discussion.
Clawdbot renames to Moltbot (GitHub Repo)

Clawdbot has been renamed to Moltbot due to the original name being too close to ‚ÄúClaude,‚Äù which is trademarked.
The Age of Pump and Dump Software (5 minute read)

A worrying new trend in 2026 is where easily generated, unmaintainable vibe-coded software is used by crypto scammers and tech FOMO for pump and dump schemes involving associated cryptocurrencies.
One Human + One Agent = One Browser From Scratch (7 minute read)

Working with a single LLM agent, the author successfully built a basic, cross-platform HTML/CSS browser from scratch in approximately 70 hours and without third-party Rust dependencies.

item.title: Rust At Scale ‚öñÔ∏è, Platform Engineering Reality üß±, Cloudflare‚Äôs Matrix ‚òÅÔ∏è
item.description:
Platform engineering teams face a measurement and value crisis, with many unable to prove ROI, drive adoption, or deliver timely results ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR DevOps 2026-01-28

TLDR is hiring a Curator for TLDR IT! (TLDR Curator, ~5 hrs/week)

We are launching a brand new newsletter covering IT and enterprise tech. We already have 500,000+ subscribers waiting for the first edition.
We need a domain expert to curate and write the daily summaries. If you want to be the voice of the IT industry, please send your resume or LinkedIn to itcurator@tldr.tech!
üì±

News & Trends

AWS Launches European Sovereign Cloud amid Questions about US Legal Jurisdiction (4 minute read)

AWS launched its European Sovereign Cloud in Germany with isolated infrastructure and EU-only operations, but analysts and practitioners question whether US laws like the CLOUD Act still allow American government access despite technical separation and a new German corporate structure.
Navigating the ingress-nginx archival: why now is the time to move to Cilium (4 minute read)

A widely used Kubernetes ingress controller, ingress-nginx, was announced at KubeCon to be archived at the start of 2026, ceasing active maintenance and security updates for the 50% of users relying on it. Organizations are now encouraged to migrate to alternatives like Cilium Ingress or the Kubernetes community's new long-term standard, the Gateway API, with utilities like `ingress2gateway` available to assist.
üöÄ

Opinions & Tutorials

Octopus and Elastic with OpenTelemetry (3 minute read)

Octopus can export audit logs via OpenTelemetry to an Elastic stack by configuring an EDOT Collector, exposing its endpoint publicly, and connecting Octopus to it, enabling centralized analysis and visualization of audit events for monitoring and security.
The platform engineering reality check: Is your initiative on track? (5 minute read)

Platform engineering teams face a measurement and value crisis, with many unable to prove ROI, drive adoption, or deliver timely results, making success dependent on clear metrics, product thinking, cultural alignment, and rapid, outcome-driven iteration rather than tools alone.
Simplify Your Code: Functional Core, Imperative Shell (2 minute read)

Separating code into a pure, side-effect-free functional core and an imperative shell for I/O makes systems easier to test, understand, and change. Business logic becomes reusable and composable, while side effects like database access or email sending are isolated and swappable.
üßë‚Äçüíª

Resources & Tools

Ralph (GitHub Repo)

Ralph, an autonomous AI agent loop based on Geoffrey Huntley's pattern, is a system that uses AI coding tools like Amp or Claude Code to complete Product Requirements Document (PRD) items. It operates through repeated iterations, with memory persisting via git history, progress.txt, and prd.json, and updates AGENTS.md with learned patterns for future runs.
1Code (GitHub Repo)

1Code.dev has launched as a new UI for Claude Code that enables local and remote agent execution across macOS, Linux, and Windows. The platform features a Cursor-like interface with diff previews, a built-in Git client, and offers pre-execution planning capabilities from Claude.
Zerobrew (GitHub Repo)

Zerobrew is a Rust-based drop-in replacement for Homebrew that boasts dramatic speed-ups between 5 - 20x.
üéÅ

Miscellaneous

Accelerate migrations with new incentives from the Rapid Migration and Modernization Program (RaMP) (2 minute read)

Google Cloud has introduced an updated Rapid Migration and Modernization Program that offers usage-based service credits, funded partner and professional services, and extra incentives for advanced workloads to help organizations modernize enterprise platforms and become AI-ready while reducing cost and complexity.
Building a serverless, post-quantum Matrix homeserver (14 minute read)

A Matrix homeserver (Synapse) was successfully ported to Cloudflare Workers in a new proof-of-concept, establishing a serverless architecture that significantly reduces operational burden and costs to under $1 monthly when idle. This innovative deployment provides global low latency (20-50ms) and built-in post-quantum TLS encryption (X25519MLKEM768).
‚ö°

Quick Links

How SurveyMonkey 2x-ed developer velocity (Sponsor)

SurveyMonkey uses mirrord to test microservices locally with access to all of their dependencies in their Kubernetes cluster. As a result they now ship 50% faster and fewer bugs reach production. See how
Amazon ECR now supports cross-repository layer sharing to optimize storage and improve push performance (2 minute read)

Amazon ECR introduced blob mounting to share image layers across repositories.
Rust at Scale: An Added Layer of Security for WhatsApp (5 minute read)

WhatsApp has increasingly adopted the Rust programming language for its media sharing functionality.

item.title: Oxygen monopolies üí≠, 4 CTA button tests üìä, invisible engagement ü´•
item.description:
Fast news cycles and rapid AI adoption mean startups win by owning a clear category early, since attention spikes fast and hardens just as quickly ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR Marketing 2026-01-28

Asana helps free up the most precious resource for marketers: Time (Sponsor)

Let's state the obvious: Creativity doesn't blossom when your team is chasing down updates, combing through spreadsheets, and wondering if so-and-so has approved the asset yet. 

Asana changes the game. When everyone is on the same page‚Äîwith AI-powered workflows, automated updates, and full visibility into campaigns‚Äîeveryone enjoys more time for creativity. 

And you don't have to take our word for it. 92% of the marketing C-suite say their teams work better together with Asana, and marketing teams experience a 22% boost in productivity. 

Give your team their creative time back. >>Try Asana today‚Äîno credit card required.

üì±

News & Trends

Oxygen Monopolies (9 minute read)

Fast news cycles and rapid AI adoption mean startups win by owning a clear category narrative early, since attention spikes fast and hardens just as quickly. AI companies now reach $10M+ ARR in under a year, and some hit $100M ARR with fewer than 100 employees, which makes early brand positioning a real competitive advantage. Strong brand association lets one company suck up most of the oxygen, as seen when it becomes shorthand for its category, like Harvey for legal AI. Brand recall now matters more than awareness, since even Tide holds 41% market share but ranks 9th on Amazon search. Companies must make people think of it first or risk being forgotten.
Introducing invisible engagement and why it matters (6 minute read)

Most consumer interaction with brand content happens through invisible actions that platforms do not track, which makes visible metrics misleading. In a study of 12,855 social media posts, only 0.6% showed visible engagement, while 22.3% showed invisible engagement and 77.1% showed none. The most common invisible actions were ‚Äòsee' at 42% and ‚Äòstop' at 41%, which signal attention without public interaction. Posts linked to invisible actions such as ‚Äòsee', ‚Äòsearch', or ‚Äòsave' had a higher median shop engagement rate of 10.1% compared to 6.8% for posts that received a ‚Äòlike'. These findings show that invisible engagement is more closely tied to purchase behavior and should play a larger role in how marketers measure performance.
üöÄ

Strategies & Tactics

4 CTA Button Tests (2 minute read)

Focus on first-person, personalized CTAs that reflect the user's role, interest, or goal, for example, ‚ÄúI want top HR tips‚Äù or ‚ÄúSave 25% on my wellness journey‚Äù. Use playful or contrasting button pairings, like ‚ÄúI hate learning new things‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúSave my seat‚Äù. Avoid generic verbs such as ‚ÄúDownload‚Äù or ‚ÄúSubmit‚Äù. Replace them with engaging, action-oriented phrases like ‚ÄúGet my discount‚Äù or ‚ÄúLet's go!‚Äù The goal is to make the CTA feel personal and clearly tied to user benefit.
Ask users to register at the start (not the end) (3 minute read)

Asking users to register at the start of shopping increases registrations, purchases, and long-term revenue. In a field experiment of over 75,000 users, early registration made shoppers 58.1% more likely to register and 10.9% more likely to buy. Those shoppers bought 16.8% more items and generated 13.2% higher total revenue over a year. Casual shoppers browsed 12.3% less after early registration prompts. Optional registration prevented short-term sales losses.
üßë‚Äçüíª

Resources & Tools

52 GTM Signals (2 minute read)

A screenshot that lists out 52 GTM triggers across 4 datasets. Start by segmenting your ICP and understanding their buyer journey. Use triggers from company activity, news, job postings, or tech changes to time outreach. Focus on high-quality, relevant data. Each signal should guide what to watch, why it matters, and how to craft your message. Right-click the screenshot and select ‚ÄúOpen in new tab‚Äù to see a zoomed-in view.
12 Steps to Winning Brand Mentions in LLMs (9 minute read)

This guide from Noble outlines 12 steps to winning LLM visibility. Start by identifying the questions your brand should appear for. Check what LLMs currently say and which sources they cite. Expand your list with high-ranking, relevant pages from Google. Clean and score all URLs to prioritize targets. Build a contact list for authors or content owners. Decide the type of mention or update needed. Craft personalized outreach at scale. Manage replies and negotiate terms or swaps. Provide easy-to-use content snippets. Implement any reciprocal mentions on your site. Verify that mentions go live and impact LLMs.
üéÅ

Miscellaneous

How do you compete in Agentic Commerce? (5 minute read)

Agentic commerce is reshaking e-commerce by turning organic search into a verification gate for AI-driven purchases rather than a traffic channel. AI agents powered about 20% of retail sales during the 2025 holiday season, and major platforms now support direct checkout through commerce protocols that bypass traditional websites. Autonomous buying mainly works in a narrow-middle since high-priced purchases resist delegation and low-priced goods already rely on subscriptions, so the real value comes from conversational commerce that compresses an average 14-click journey into 1 or 2 steps. The protocols force merchants to optimize structured product data and APIs instead of pages. As a result, SEO shifts from driving clicks to feeding trusted, granular data into AI systems, favoring incumbents for broad intent and specialists for specific intent.
There are Reasons to Be Bullish About AI Chat Ads (4 minute read)

AI chat ads could reshape retail media, but their success is uncertain. OpenAI and Google are testing ads in ChatGPT and Gemini, while Amazon and Walmart explore AI-powered shopping. Experts say AI ads could combine strong intent and deep user knowledge, offering personalized experiences if they feel helpful rather than pushy. Retailers want to stay the merchant of record and control logistics, limiting AI's transactional role. Widespread adoption could disrupt retail media by capturing intent and transaction data, but user experience and partner balance remain key challenges.
Why Search and Shopping ads stop scaling without demand (8 minute read)

Search and Shopping ads capture existing demand but don't create it. Growth stalls when the audience or queries are limited, not because campaigns are broken. Broad match and AI Max can stretch coverage slightly, but they still rely on search activity. True growth requires creating demand upstream through content, SEO, social, and paid media.
‚ö°

Quick Links

Please Stop Selling Like It's 2021 (3 minute read)

In 2026, B2B wins with self-serve, zero-friction value, or buyers will build it themselves with AI.
5 email predictions for the charitable sector (1 minute read)

Nonprofits should show gratitude year-round, focus on story-driven content, and ditch generic mail-merged templates.
Meta Is Preparing To Test Premium Subscriptions Across Its Apps (2 minute read)

The strategy targets power users and everyday consumers alike, betting that meaningful control and AI features can justify payment despite growing subscription fatigue.

item.title: Meta is blocking links to ICE List
item.description:
PLUS: Welcome to the ‚ÄòOffline Club‚Äô.

View in browser  |  Your newsletter preferences

01.28.26

 
 

POLITICS

Meta Is Blocking Links to ICE List on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads

BY DAVID GILBERT | 2-MINUTE READ

Users of Meta‚Äôs social platforms can no longer share links to ICE List, a website listing what it claims are the names of thousands of DHS employees.

 
 

BUSINESS

Google DeepMind Staffers Ask Leaders to Keep Them ‚ÄòPhysically Safe‚Äô From ICE

BY MAXWELL ZEFF | 3-MINUTE READ

A federal agent allegedly tried to enter Google‚Äôs Cambridge campus in the fall, WIRED has learned. Now, staffers want policies that protect them from immigration officials.

 
 

CULTURE

The State-Led Crackdown on Grok and xAI Has Begun

BY MADDY VARNER AND MANISHA KRISHNAN | 6-MINUTE READ

At least 37 attorneys general for US states and territories are taking action against xAI after Grok generated a flood of nonconsensual sexual images of women and minors.

 
 

CULTURE

Pornhub Will Block New UK Users Starting Next Week to Protest ‚ÄòFlawed‚Äô ID Law

BY MANISHA KRISHNAN | 2-MINUTE READ

Only users who have already registered and completed age verification will be able to access the world's largest porn site.

ADVERTISEMENT

 
 

CULTURE

No Phone, No Social Safety Net: Welcome to the ‚ÄòOffline Club‚Äô

BY JOEL KHALILI | 5-MINUTE READ

Across Europe‚Äôs largest cities, people are gathering for semi-silent, offline hangouts, in search of an experience that isn‚Äôt mediated through their smartphones.

 
 

ROBOTICS

This Humanoid Is Ready to Bring You a Toothbrush

BY WILL KNIGHT | 2-MINUTE READ

Fauna, a new startup, is betting that humanoid robots will find success as hospitality workers, research assistants, and entertainers.

 
 

ELECTRIC VEHICLES

New Data Shows Robotaxis Competing on Price‚Äîand Speed

BY AARIAN MARSHALL | 2-MINUTE READ

Research from the ride-hail aggregator Obi finds Waymo is starting to edge up on Uber and Lyft in San Francisco. Tesla, which operates a ride-hail service with human drivers, is winning the price wars.

 
 

GEAR

Amazon Is Rolling Out Alexa+ to All Users. But Not Everyone Wants It

BY NENA FARRELL | 4-MINUTE READ

Alexa+ has been rolling out to everyone with a Prime membership, even if you didn‚Äôt ask for it. Here‚Äôs how to change it back.

 
 

GEAR

Google‚Äôs Smart Glasses Will Have the Best Software. But They‚Äôll Have to Win on Style Too

BY BOONE ASHWORTH | 4-MINUTE READ

When Google releases its smart glasses in the coming months, the strength of its AI-powered software will be its biggest leg up on its rivals. But will people want to be seen wearing them?

Yahoo Scout is a new AI-powered 'answer engine' powered by Anthropic's Claude. It synthesizes information from the web and Yahoo's own data ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR 2026-01-28

TLDR is hiring a Curator for TLDR IT! (TLDR Curator, ~5 hrs/week)

We are launching a brand new newsletter covering IT and enterprise tech. We already have 500,000+ subscribers waiting for the first edition.
We need a domain expert to curate and write the daily summaries. If you want to be the voice of the IT industry, please send your resume or LinkedIn to itcurator@tldr.tech!
üì±

Big Tech & Startups

Yahoo is adding generative AI to its search engine (1 minute read)

Yahoo Scout is a new AI-powered 'answer engine' powered by Anthropic's Claude. It synthesizes information from the web and Yahoo's own data when constructing responses to natural language queries. The interface includes visible source links aimed at making answers easier to verify. The engine behind Scout will become more personalized as time goes on.
Amazon to Shut Down All Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh Stores (2 minute read)

Amazon is closing all Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh physical stores and will shift its focus to online same-day delivery and expand its Whole Foods market business. The Go and Fresh stores failed to deliver a distinctive customer experience and couldn't be scaled up. Some of the shuttered stores will be converted into Whole Foods stores. Amazon plans to open 100 new Whole Foods stores in the coming years.
üöÄ

Science & Futuristic Technology

Automating Biology (22 minute read)

Biology is wildly complex, and our understanding of biological systems is just scratching the surface. Automating biology will require significant investment to achieve exit velocity. However, once we achieve it, we'll be able to explore the galaxies of genes, proteins, and microbes living all around us. These developments will pave the way for novel therapeutics that will improve health and longevity, boost biomanufacturing, and more.
Introducing Helix 02: Full-Body Autonomy (11 minute read)

Helix 2 is a single neural system that can control a full humanoid robot body directly from pixels. It enables continuous, room-scale autonomy that seamlessly blends walking and manipulation. This article details what Helix 2 is capable of. It contains several clips of the Figure 03 robot performing tasks while running on the new system.
üíª

Programming, Design & Data Science

Stop vibe messing and start vibe shipping with v0 by Vercel (Sponsor)

Let's face it: vibe coding has resulted in a lot of demos, but not a lot of software. With v0 by Vercel, that's no longer the case. v0 is built for production apps and agents, including enterprise-grade security and integrations that enable teams to reliably ship real software, not just spin up demos. Start shipping with v0.
Try text scaling support in Chrome Canary (7 minute read)

The new 'meta name=text-scale' HTML tag informs browsers that websites are designed to still work if users increase their OS text size. To support text scaling, developers should avoid overriding the initial font size, only use font-relative units for content, and test on devices to quickly figure out problem areas and think about how to adapt their layouts. The tag is currently supported in Chrome Canary with the 'Experimental Web Platform features' flag enabled. Support in other browsers will hopefully come later this year.
One Human + One Agent = One Browser From Scratch (2 minute read)

one-agent-one-browser is a web browser built in three days with a single Codex CLI agent. It contains 20,000 lines of Rust with no Rust crate dependencies at all, with only OS system frameworks for image and text rendering. The browser successfully renders HTML and CSS and can even display SVGs and PNGs. The project proves that an agent driven by a talented engineer is enough to get a very solid basic renderer working.
üéÅ

Miscellaneous

Amazon inadvertently announces cloud unit layoffs in email to employees (2 minute read)

Amazon erroneously sent out a notice to cloud staffers on Tuesday acknowledging organizational changes at the company. The company is expected to announce widespread layoffs across its corporate workforce as soon as this week. The layoffs are meant to reduce management layers and bureaucracy inside the company. The efficiency gains from AI will likely further shrink Amazon's corporate staff count in the coming years.
‚ÄúIG is a drug‚Äù: Internal messages may doom Meta at social media addiction trial (7 minute read)

A high-profile lawsuit against Meta and YouTube that alleges the companies caused psychological harm by designing features like infinite scroll and autoplay is set to begin this week. The case could set a meaningful precedent for hundreds of other complaints. TikTok and Snapchat were also targeted by the lawsuit, but both have settled. The lawsuit seeks untold damages, including potentially punitive damages, to help the plaintiff's family recoup losses and to punish social media companies and deter them from promoting harmful features to kids.
‚ö°

Quick Links

Make your raw meeting notes awesome with Granola. No awkward meeting bot required (Sponsor)

Granola takes your raw call notes and enriches them in the exact format your team needs. You then share or prompt it to draft follow ups ‚Äî even on iPhone. Get Granola
Meta to test premium subscription plans for Instagram, Facebook, and WhatsApp (2 minute read)

The subscriptions will give paid users access to more features and extended AI capabilities.
Claude Code made me love meetings again (3 minute read)

Claude frees up mental capacity and increases your capacity for getting interrupted.
Pinterest laying off 15% of workforce as part of AI push; stock plummets (2 minute read)

Pinterest expects the cuts to be complete by late September.
Blocking Claude (2 minute read)

Claude will refuse to answer questions about pages if they contain a specific string.
Mozilla is building an AI ‚Äòrebel alliance' to take on industry heavyweights OpenAI, Anthropic (13 minute read)

Mozilla will deploy roughly $1.4 billion worth of reserves to support startups that are working on safety and governance issues in AI.
Crypto giant Tether pushes into the US with USAT stablecoin to challenge Circle (2 minute read)

Tether's to USAT is a stablecoin designed to be compliant with US regulations.

item.title: ü¶û Viral AI agent molts past trademark trouble
item.description:
PLUS: Moonshot‚Äôs K2.5 open-source model rivals frontier labs  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

  Read Online

Read Online | Sign Up | Advertise

Good morning, vibex. Anthropic made Clawdbot change its name, but that didn‚Äôt stop the lobster‚Äôs momentum.

The viral AI agent is now Moltbot, and it‚Äôs been taking the internet by storm from within chat apps ‚Äî providing a glimpse of an agentic future that actually works, though full device access means the risks are just as real.

 

In today‚Äôs AI rundown:

  • Viral AI agent takes the internet by storm

  • OpenAI releases free scientific writing workspace

  • Find dozens of free AI tools with Google Labs

  • Moonshot‚Äôs K2.5 open-source model rivals frontier labs

  • 4 new AI tools, community workflows, and more

LATEST DEVELOPMENTS

AI AGENTS

ü¶û¬†Viral AI agent takes the internet by storm

Image source: Lovart / The Rundown

The Rundown: Open-source AI assistant Moltbot (formerly Clawdbot) has gone viral for its impressive agentic capabilities, operating 24/7 from within Telegram or WhatsApp ‚Äî though experts warn its full system access comes with serious risks.

The details:

  • Moltbot runs locally and connects to users‚Äô digital lives, proactively taking actions and messaging via chat apps when tasks are done.

  • The tool was renamed after Anthropic reached out over trademark concerns, with creator Peter Steinberger initially launching it as Clawdbot in December.

  • Viral demos range from negotiating and purchasing a new car to calling a restaurant via ElevenLabs after failing to book through OpenTable.

  • Many are warning of the security risks associated with full device access, including prompt injections, exposed data, and more if not properly managed.

Why it matters: Moltbot looks like a serious step up in the agentic world that actually delivers: running autonomously, keeping context across sessions, and taking real actions. But the utility comes with risk ‚Äî full access to messages, credentials, and systems means a single exploit may compromise everything if not set up correctly.

TOGETHER WITH SYNK

üö©¬†Test your security skills live

The Rundown: Snyk‚Äôs annual Fetch the Flag CTF is back ‚Äî a 24-hour virtual Capture the Flag competition hosted with NahamSec on Feb. 12th, where security pros can sharpen their skills and compete for prizes.

Here's what you can expect:

  • 15 hands-on hacking challenges spanning web exploitation, binary, and OSINT

  • CPE credit to boost your professional development credentials

  • Rokid AR Joy 2 Glasses for top 3 teams and top 3 individual players

Register now.

OPENAI

üî¨¬†OpenAI releases free scientific writing workspace

Image source: OpenAI

The Rundown: OpenAI just launched Prism, a free research tool that puts its most advanced reasoning model inside the scientific writing process ‚Äî aiming to do for research what AI coding assistants did for software development over the past year.

The details:

  • The tool came from OpenAI‚Äôs acquisition of Crixet, a cloud-based science writing platform, which it rebuilt around its latest GPT 5.2 reasoning model.

  • Scientists can search for papers, auto-generate citations, and turn photos of whiteboard math into formatted equations, without leaving the document.

  • OpenAI revealed ChatGPT fields over 8M weekly queries on hard science topics, suggesting researchers are already leaning heavily on AI.

  • The free tool has no caps on team size or projects, a departure from typical expensive academic software pricing models.

Why it matters: Since ChatGPT‚Äôs launch, journals have been drowning in sloppy papers full of made-up citations and errors. OAI‚Äôs argument is that the problem was never AI in research ‚Äî it was researchers using it blindly without context. An integrated tool like Prism could be the difference between slop and real acceleration.

AI TRAINING

üõ†Ô∏è¬†Find dozens of free AI tools with Google Labs

The Rundown:¬†In this tutorial, you will learn how to use Google Labs‚Äô free AI tools to build marketing content for your business. There are dozens of overlooked tools to help tackle whatever your use case may be, but we‚Äôve selected our top three here.

Step-by-step:

  1. Navigate to¬†labs.google/experiments¬†to see a full list of tools.

  2. First is¬†Pomelli. Copy your brand‚Äôs website URL and paste it into Pomelli. After ~5 minutes, you‚Äôll get bespoke ad campaigns with image and video assets.

  3. Next, use¬†Flow. Create start and end frames via¬†Create Image, add them to¬†Frames to Video¬†with a prompt, then stitch clips using the scene builder.

  4. Finally, go to¬†ImageFX¬†for image iteration. Use the suggested styles to polish up your prompting skills and try locking the ‚Äúseed‚Äù to keep outputs consistent.

Pro tip:¬†Click the dropdown beside ImageFX and select MusicFX for generating music.

PRESENTED BY CONTEXTUAL AI

ü§ñ¬†Introducing Agent Composer

The Rundown: Agent Composer helps teams tackle expert-level engineering tasks in high-stakes environments ‚Äî compressing hours of complex routine work into minutes. Trusted by high-tech leaders like Qualcomm and Advantest, it‚Äôs built for environments where accuracy and reliability are non-negotiable.

What makes it different:

  • Unified context layer gives agents full visibility into tasks, data, and workflow context

  • Controlled agents combine dynamic intelligence with structured workflows for mission-critical reliability

  • No-code builder with pre-built templates, natural language prompts, or visual drag-and-drop

See it in action today and read the launch blog.

MOONSHOT AI

üá®üá≥¬†Moonshot‚Äôs K2.5 open-source model rivals frontier labs

Image source: Moonshot AI

The Rundown: Chinese AI startup Moonshot just open-sourced Kimi K2.5, a new 1T-parameter model that rivals GPT-5.2 and Claude Opus 4.5 across coding, vision, and agentic benchmarks. The release includes Kimi Code, a terminal-based coding agent.

The details:

  • K2.5 tops GPT-5.2 and Opus 4.5 in on key benchmarks for agentic tasks and video reasoning, though it trails slightly on pure coding evals.

  • K2.5 shows massive cost savings over top rivals, is natively multimodal, and comes in as the top open model on Artificial Analysis‚Äô leaderboard.

  • The model also features Agent Swarm, allowing K2.5 to manage up to 100 AI sub-agents running tasks at once across up to 1,500 steps and tools.

  • Moonshot also open-sourced Kimi Code, an agentic coding agent that works in terminals and IDEs like VSCode and Cursor.

Why it matters: The gap between open-source and closed frontier models keeps shrinking ‚Äî and once again, it‚Äôs a Chinese lab leading the charge. With DeepSeek‚Äôs V4 also reportedly on deck, U.S. labs are facing pressure from multiple directions as China‚Äôs open wave keeps building at costs that are hard for top labs to compete with.

QUICK HITS

üõ†Ô∏è Trending AI Tools

  • üí∏¬†Nume - The world‚Äôs first AI CFO that every startup and SME needs. Connect to Xero and QuickBooks in 5 minutes*

  • ü¶û¬†Moltbot (formerly Clawdbot) - Open-source personal AI assistant that lives in chat apps

  • üöÄ¬†Kimi K2.5 - Moonshot AI‚Äôs powerful, open-source agent-focused model

  • üé•¬†Ray 3.14 - Luma‚Äôs upgraded video model for professional creative workflows

*Sponsored Listing

üì∞¬†Everything else in AI today

Luma AI¬†released Ray3.14, an upgraded video generation model that outputs native 1080p while running significantly faster and cheaper than its predecessor.

DeepSeek open-sourced OCR 2, a model for reading and extracting text from documents that tops benchmarks while being much more efficient with tokens.

AI2 introduced SERA, a new family of open-source coding agents able to be cheaply trained on private codebases with native support for Claude Code.

Google¬†premiered ‚ÄòDear Upstairs Neighbors‚Äô at Sundance, an animated short made with its video AI in collaboration with artists to replicate hand-painted styles.

Alibaba‚Äôs Tongyi Lab open-sourced Z-Image, the full base version of its Z-Image Turbo, which ranked as the top open-source image model in December.

COMMUNITY

ü§ù¬†Community AI workflows

Every newsletter, we showcase how a reader is using AI to work smarter, save time, or make life easier.

Today‚Äôs workflow comes from reader Brendan O. in Crofton, MD:

‚ÄúI use Kilo Code‚Äôs Managed Indexing to find code I know exists but can‚Äôt name exactly. In large codebases, I often need to locate logic or patterns without remembering file or function names, and regular text search just doesn‚Äôt cut it.

Managed Indexing lets me describe what I‚Äôm looking for in plain English and get the right code back quickly, which makes the difference between saving an hour and losing your train of thought.‚Äù

How do you use AI? Tell us here.

üéì Highlights: News, Guides & Events

  • Read our last AI newsletter: Anthropic CEO confronts AI‚Äôs dangers

  • Read our last Tech newsletter: TikTok USA‚Äôs epic meltdown

  • Read our last Robotics newsletter: Musk‚Äôs Optimus deadline

  • Today‚Äôs AI tool guide: Find dozens of free AI tools with Google Labs

  • RSVP to our next workshop on Feb. 11: Agentic Workflows Bootcamp pt. 1

That's it for today!

Before you go we‚Äôd love to know what you thought of today's newsletter to help us improve The Rundown experience for you.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è Nailed it

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è Average

‚≠êÔ∏è Fail

See you soon,

Rowan, Joey, Zach, Shubham, and Jennifer ‚Äî the humans behind The Rundown

Want to sponsor us and get in front of 1,000,000+ AI enthusiasts?¬†Get in touch.

Keep up with everything Tech? Join The Rundown Tech.

item.title: C3.AI in Talks to Merge with Startup Automation Anywhere
item.description:
C3.AI in Talks to Merge with Startup Automation Anywhere
C3.AI, founded by tech industry veteran Thomas Siebel, is in talks to merge with privately held startup Automation Anywhere, which will effectively go public in the deal, according to people familiar with the discussions. C3.AI, which sells AI to large companies and government agencies, was the first branded AI stock when it went public in 2020. It has struggled for several years amid the rise of generative AI and its market cap has slid to $1.7 billion, a tenth of its valuation six years ago. Automation Anywhere, a rival to UiPath, develops software for automating repetitive tasks inside businesses. If the deal materializes, Automation Anywhere would buy C3.AI and go public as a result, the people said.
Jan 27, 2026

Exclusive

C3.AI in Talks to Merge with Startup Automation Anywhere

By Valida Pau and Katie Roof

C3.AI, founded by tech industry veteran Thomas Siebel, is in talks to merge with privately held startup Automation Anywhere, which will effectively go public in the deal, according to people familiar with the discussions.

C3.AI, which sells AI to large companies and government agencies, was the first branded AI stock when it went public in 2020. It has struggled for several years amid the rise of generative AI and its market cap has slid to $1.7 billion, a tenth of its valuation six years ago. Automation Anywhere, a rival to UiPath, develops software for automating repetitive tasks inside businesses. If the deal materializes, Automation Anywhere would buy C3.AI and go public as a result, the people said.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • C3.AI in talks to merge with startup Automation Anywhere, which would go public
  • C3.AI market cap slid to $1.7 billion, a tenth of its valuation six years ago
  • Automation Anywhere would go public via merger, gaining AI automation capabilities

item.title: Exclusive: Anthropic Hikes 2026 Revenue Forecast 20% as It Seeks to Narrow Gap With OpenAI
item.description:
Anthropic Hikes 2026 Revenue Forecast 20% but Delays When It Will Go Cash Flow Positive
Anthropic has hiked its revenue forecasts for the next several years, projecting that sales will quadruple this year to as much as $18 billion and will hit $55 billion next year. It is aiming to shrink the revenue gap with OpenAI, its older archrival. The revenue projections, which haven‚Äôt previously been reported, are significantly higher than the ones Anthropic made last summer. But expenses, including those from training and running its AI models, are also growing more quickly, outstripping revenue. As a result, Anthropic has delayed when it expects to be cash flow positive to 2028, a year later than its previous projections, according to the forecasts. That extra cash burn could weigh on investors‚Äô minds ahead of its public offering, which investment bankers expect could happen as soon as late this year.
Jan 27, 2026

Exclusive

Anthropic Hikes 2026 Revenue Forecast 20% but Delays When It Will Go Cash Flow Positive

By Sri Muppidi

Anthropic has hiked its revenue forecasts for the next several years, projecting that sales will quadruple this year to as much as $18 billion and will hit $55 billion next year. It is aiming to shrink the revenue gap with OpenAI, its older archrival.

The revenue projections, which haven‚Äôt previously been reported, are significantly higher than the ones Anthropic made last summer. But expenses, including those from training and running its AI models, are also growing more quickly, outstripping revenue. As a result, Anthropic has delayed when it expects to be cash flow positive to 2028, a year later than its previous projections, according to the forecasts. That extra cash burn could weigh on investors‚Äô minds ahead of its public offering, which investment bankers expect could happen as soon as late this year.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Anthropic projects 2025 revenue to hit $55 billion
  • Company delays becoming cash flow positive until 2028
  • Anthropic’s AI model training costs to exceed $100 billion by 2029

item.title: The Briefing: Amazon‚Äôs Fresh Expires
item.description:
The Briefing
It‚Äôs a good thing Jeff Bezos started Amazon as an internet-based retailer. He might never have made it as a traditional shopkeeper! ͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 27, 2026

The Briefing
By Martin Peers

Greetings!

It‚Äôs a good thing Jeff Bezos started Amazon as an internet-based retailer. He might never have made it as a traditional shopkeeper! Amazon on Tuesday said it would shutter its chain of Amazon Fresh and Amazon Go grocery stores, closing a chapter in its fitful efforts to expand in physical stores. Amazon still owns the Whole Foods chain it bought in 2017, which the company says it will be expanding. But for now, it seems Amazon is focusing most of its grocery ambitions online, such as its new fast-delivery service, Amazon Now. (As a side note, can you imagine being on the team at Amazon tasked with coming up with new brand names? Amazon Go, Fresh, Now, Prime, and so on and so on!)

It would be churlish to criticize Amazon for the various twists and turns of its Amazon Fresh adventures. After all, one of the company‚Äôs great strengths is its willingness to make mistakes and not get bogged down in recriminations later. But just keeping straight the current strategy for Amazon groceries is a full-time job. Conceived before the pandemic, Fresh was initially meant to create a network of stores that could both help with delivery of online grocery orders and offer lower prices than Whole Foods for shoppers. Some Fresh stores also initially used new technology‚ÄîAmazon‚Äôs vaunted ‚ÄúJust Walk Out‚Äù tech‚Äîthat could eliminate checkout lines.¬†

The technology piece in particular was a laudable aim. Who hasn‚Äôt stood in line at a grocery store checkout and fumed at the failure of the industry to innovate? Automated checkouts are great, but the idea of walking out without checking out is even better. Unfortunately, as Amazon found, the technology brought with it lots of problems, which didn‚Äôt help Fresh‚Äôs prospects. Then there was the pandemic, which scrambled things in retail, temporarily killing consumers‚Äô desire to buy in a store. After the pandemic, Amazon tried to reboot Fresh, without the tech and with brighter colors in the stores. The results, the company says, were good‚Äîbut what has proved more popular with consumers has been its array of online grocery-delivery services. Understandably, Amazon is opting to invest more money in those offerings. That makes sense. Online orders are, after all, in the company‚Äôs DNA. (As a side note, my colleague Ann Gehan predicted Amazon would close the Fresh stores this year).

This raises the question of why Amazon continues to dabble in bricks-and-mortar stores at all. For instance, why keep Whole Foods? Well, it‚Äôs obviously got a better brand name. And the company tells me the chain is delivering bigger increases in revenue than Fresh. It also gives Amazon a chance to continue testing new tech (love the palm readers!). Then there‚Äôs the question of why Amazon is now trying out a big-box format. In Amazon‚Äôs telling, those stores, one of a couple of ‚Äúnew physical store experiences‚Äù it is trying, reflect its desire to experiment. Amazon seems to be following the old adage: If at first you don‚Äôt succeed, try, try again.

TikTok‚Äôs Legal Exit

TikTok, the app that you might say exemplifies addictive social media, settled the first bellwether lawsuit regarding social media addiction on Tuesday morning, just as the case was due to go to trial. Snap settled last week, so TikTok‚Äôs settlement leaves just Meta Platforms and Google‚Äôs YouTube as defendants.

The lawsuit is the first of thousands of cases to be tried, each designed to test whether social media companies can be held liable for allegedly addictive product designs plaintiffs say are causing a mental health crisis among youth. The first case on the docket was brought by a now-20-year-old girl from Chico, Calif., who is alleging that her social media addiction contributed to depression and suicidal thoughts. That‚Äôs certainly bad optics for the two companies. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Instagram head Adam Mosseri are both expected to testify in court, where they will be grilled over decisions they made on safety.¬†

YouTube spent its pretrial briefing last week trying to convince journalists it should be considered a streaming platform, not a social media company, and now it‚Äôll be the sole co-defendant alongside Meta, the plaintiffs‚Äô biggest target. For that reason, it‚Äôs not crazy to think YouTube could settle at any moment. But lawyers I spoke to say it‚Äôs unlikely the plaintiffs would let Meta in particular off the hook by agreeing to settle, given the weight of the evidence against it (helped along by the documents initially leaked by Frances Haugen, the Facebook whistleblower).¬†

Regardless, there‚Äôs another trial due to start shortly after this one finishes, expected in a couple months. TikTok and Snap remain defendants in that and other cases. As we explained on Monday, once the first few cases are resolved, both sides are likely to use the outcome to fashion a global settlement covering all of the cases.‚ÄîErin Woo¬†

In Other News

‚Ä¢¬†Meta Platforms plans to test premium subscriptions on its apps in the next few months, TechCrunch reported. The subscriptions would offer access to exclusive features, including ‚Äúexpanded AI capabilities,‚Äù TechCrunch said.

‚Ä¢¬†As more tech executives weigh in on the weekend‚Äôs fatal shooting by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman told staff this week that he believes ‚ÄúICE is going too far,‚Äù according to a copy of the internal memo published by The New York Times‚Äô DealBook.

‚Ä¢¬†The average price to ride in Waymo‚Äôs robotaxis has dropped 3.6% since March to $19.69 per ride, according to a new report by ride-hailing analytics firm Obi. Meanwhile, Uber and Lyft have raised their average prices.

‚Ä¢¬†Pinterest said Tuesday it will lay off up to 15% of its employees, or around 700 staffers, as part of a restructuring to put more resources toward AI-focused projects.

‚Ä¢¬†Moonshot AI, a Chinese large-language model developer, released its new foundation model, Kimi K2.5, saying it excels in coding as well as understanding visual data.

Today on The Information‚Äôs TITV

Check out our latest episode of TITV in which editor in chief Jessica Lessin offers her thoughts on the current political debates consuming Silicon Valley.

Recommended Newsletter

Start your day with Applied AI, the newsletter from The Information that uncovers how leading businesses are leveraging AI to automate tasks across the board. Subscribe now for free to get it delivered straight to your inbox twice a week.


New From Our Reporters

Data Point

AI Clogs Exits for PE-Backed Software Firms

By Valida Pau

Upcoming Events

Wednesday, January 28 ‚Äî Inside Davos With Jessica Lessin: What Global Leaders Are Focused on Now

Join The Information Founder and Editor-in-Chief Jessica Lessin for a subscriber-only live session drawing on her reporting from the World Economic Forum in Davos.

item.title: Dealmaker: PE Pins Hopes on Cluster of Software IPOs
item.description:
Dealmaker
As I wrote earlier today, private equity firms are sitting on a backlog of software companies they bought during the buyout frenzy of 2021 and 2022 that they hope to take public or sell.¬† One reason they can‚Äôt cash out is that the initial public offering market has not been receptive to new PE-backed software listings. The value of all PE-backed software companies totaled just $17 billion from 2022 to 2024, less than one-fifth of the deals in 2021, according to PitchBook.¬† That lukewarm appetite may extend into this year, thanks to the distraction of the planned¬† blockbuster IPO of SpaceX and expectations that OpenAI, Anthropic and Databricks could follow.
Jan 27, 2026

Dealmaker
By Valida Pau

Welcome back!

As I wrote earlier today, private equity firms are sitting on a backlog of software companies they bought during the buyout frenzy of 2021 and 2022 that they hope to take public or sell.¬†

One reason they can‚Äôt cash out is that the initial public offering market has not been receptive to new PE-backed software listings. The value of all PE-backed software companies totaled just $17 billion from 2022 to 2024, less than one-fifth of the deals in 2021, according to PitchBook.¬†

That lukewarm appetite may extend into this year, thanks to the distraction of the planned¬† blockbuster IPO of SpaceX and expectations that OpenAI, Anthropic and Databricks could follow.

‚ÄúGenerally speaking, I think the environment for PE-backed IPOs is going to be more difficult than [that for] VC-backed ones, with the exception of certain vertical software and security companies,‚Äù said Jonathan Cofsky, a technology portfolio manager at mutual fund manager Janus Henderson.¬†

One of the reasons PE-owned software listings are getting little interest is that investors fancy high-growth stories rather than PE-backed companies, which are often older with slower growth rates, say investors in IPOs and investment bankers that underwrite new listings. Plus, investors are worried these companies won‚Äôt be able to adapt to AI quickly.¬†

Companies that were taken private a few years ago would be returning to the public market after massive sell-offs of software-related stocks, driven by the fear that AI tools and applications would replace demand for the enterprise software companies‚Äô products.¬†

‚ÄúThat was just a very different time for software when the growth rates were much higher and the investors were willing to pay a lot more for software. Most importantly, generative AI wasn‚Äôt a thing,‚Äù Cofsky said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that PE had the wrong thesis, it‚Äôs just the world changed.‚Äù¬†

And the few that went public have met with a chilly reception. Shares of Thoma Bravo‚Äìbacked SailPoint Technologies, the only PE-backed software IPO last year, have fallen 20% since its listing in February.¬†

The successful IPO of Medline last December gave PE investors hope that listings outside generic corporate software would succeed. The medical supply firm owned by Blackstone raised $6 billion, the most money raised in any offering last year, and the stock has soared more than 50% since its debut.

Possible IPO contenders this year among PE-backed companies include Liftoff, a mobile app ‚Äãmarketing company owned by Blackstone, which filed IPO paperwork publicly two weeks ago. Genesys, a customer experience software maker backed by Permira and Hellman & Friedman, which delayed a listing last year, could eye an IPO in the coming months as well, according to a person familiar with the discussion.¬†

Thoma Bravo has explored in recent months taking at least two of its cybersecurity companies this year‚ÄîPing Identity and Proofpoint‚Äîpublic this year, according to people with knowledge of the matter.¬†

How these PE-backed companies perform in the public market will likely determine whether PE firms can manage to chip away at a bigger chunk of their private holdings.¬†

If they are looking for lessons from last year, they would lower their price expectations. Over two-thirds of 2025 tech IPOs trade below their listing price. Some investors in those small and midsize deals blame the weak performance on companies and their bankers for pricing the stocks too high.

Today on TITV

David Levy of Porch Capital speaks about Nvidia‚Äôs deepening ties to CoreWeave and the future of edge inference.

item.title: AI Agenda: OpenAI One-Ups Anthropic with New Whistleblower Policy
item.description:
AI Agenda
OpenAI recently updated its policy for handling whistleblower complaints, responding to complaints about AI startups ignoring what are standard rules applying to all companies. It follows similar steps from Anthropic and could pressure other AI companies to follow suit. ͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 27, 2026

AI Agenda
By Rocket Drew
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! I‚Äôd love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign up¬†here.

Hello! Rocket here.

OpenAI recently updated its policy for handling whistleblower complaints, following concerns about AI startups ignoring what are standard rules applying to all companies. It follows similar steps from Anthropic and could pressure other AI companies to follow suit.¬†

Federal government rules mandate that companies cannot retaliate against employees who report wrongdoing. Legislation governing AI, including the E.U. AI Act and California‚Äôs SB 53,¬†has specifically mandated the protections for AI firms. But OpenAI, Anthropic and other AI companies have lobbied against laws containing whistleblower protections, arguing that they could expose trade secrets. OpenAI landed in hot water in May 2024 for an under-the-radar policy that required departing employees to sign non-disparagement agreements to keep their vested equity. (Whistleblowers even asked the Securities Exchange Commission to investigate, but that policy has since been removed.)¬†

A year ago, the AI Whistleblowing Initiative was founded in Berlin to research and advocate for whistleblower protections at AI companies and to support individual whistleblowers. While some companies were supportive, the initial reaction to its efforts wasn‚Äôt entirely friendly. When AIWI ran a campaign last year asking AI companies to publish their whistleblowing policies, one unnamed company sent the organization a cease-and-desist letter.

Karl Koch, founder of the AI Whistleblowing Initiative, said he met with an executive at OpenAI earlier this month to discuss AIWI‚Äôs recommendations for improving the previous version of OpenAI‚Äôs policy, which was published in 2024. AIWI is releasing the report containing those recommendations Tuesday, along with its initial reactions to OpenAI‚Äôs updated policy, Koch said.¬†

Of the 13 recommendations AIWI made, OpenAI partially or fully addressed eight of them. For instance, the new policy clarifies that OpenAI‚Äôs compliance team is in charge of handling these reports. It also lays out protections for employees in particular countries, and even links to the California Attorney General‚Äôs whistleblowing hotline.

However, Koch cautioned that there are still many unanswered questions about OpenAI‚Äôs internal reporting channels, including how the board of directors and lawyers are involved in handling complaints, and whether the policy is legally binding.¬†

Still, Koch says OpenAI‚Äôs new policy is the strongest whistleblowing policy that any of the leading AI companies have published. It goes further than Anthropic‚Äôs, which was published in December. Anthropic‚Äôs version is narrowly focused on employees reporting violations of its own safety and security policy and lacks a timeline when it pledges to respond to complaints.¬†

A spokesperson for Anthropic said in a statement that the company has a non-retaliation policy similar to OpenAI‚Äôs that covers additional topics, such as fraud and conflicts of interest, including an anonymous reporting line. Anthropic has also said employees do not have to sign non-disparagement agreements that would make it difficult for them to publicly raise safety concerns.

For any employees that are considering raising concerns, Koch recommends starting by talking to a lawyer, who can review other relevant documents, such as an employee handbook. Employees can also anonymously contact AIWI, which can put them in contact with lawyers that work on whistleblowing cases pro bono.

Here‚Äôs what else is going on‚Ä¶

Dario‚Äôs Revision Quest

Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei published an essay Monday outlining how he sees the risks from powerful AI, such as the possibility of AI taking over the world or empowering an authoritarian regime. While he ventured into some fresh territory, such as arguing that AI companies themselves could pose authoritarian risks, he mostly pieced together ideas that would be familiar to Anthropic-ologists.¬†

The bigger surprises came after the essay was published. First, Amodei posted on X that ‚Äúgiven the horror we‚Äôre seeing in Minnesota, its emphasis on the importance of preserving democratic values and rights at home is particularly relevant.‚Äù That statement made Amodei one of the highest-profile tech executives to weigh in on the Minneapolis killing.

The second surprise was that Claude was not responsible for its word count, which exceeded 21,000 words, though it was drafted in only three days. While Claude assisted Amodei with editing and research, Amodei has said that he himself handled the writing. Then again, if I had an editor that could read up to 2 million tokens per minute, I would probably end up writing 21,000-word articles too.

Deals and Debuts

See The Information‚Äôs Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

SoftBank halted talks to acquire Switch, a U.S.-based data center operator, for around $50 billion, Bloomberg reported. Both sides are still negotiating a potential investment or partnership, according to the report.

StepFun, which develops large language models and has partnered with smartphone brands, raised over $700 million in a Series B funding round.

Ricursive Technologies, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based AI lab building AI that can improve chip designs, raised $300 million in Series A funding at a $4 billion valuation led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

DeepWay, which develops self-driving technology for trucking, raised $173 million ahead of an IPO from investors including ABC Impact, Lenovo Capital, Puhua Capital and Sunwoda Electronic Co., Bloomberg reported.

Tandem, which uses AI to automate pharmacy paperwork, is raising $100 million at a $1 billion valuation in a funding round led by Accel, Bloomberg reported.

Zocks, which provides AI for financial advisors, raised $45 million in a Series B funding round led by Lightspeed Venture Partners and QED Investors.

Flora, an AI-powered design app, raised $42 million in Series A funding led by Redpoint Ventures.

Pace, an agentic insurance startup, raised $10 million in Series A funding led by Sequoia Capital.

SpotDraft, which develops on-device contract review tech for regulated legal workflows, raised $8 million in Series B funding from Qualcomm Ventures.

Midship, a San Francisco-based startup that builds AI for accounting fraud testing, raised $4.2 million in seed funding led by Costanoa Ventures.

The European Union has opened a formal investigation into Elon Musk‚Äôs X over how the social media service has integrated xAI‚Äôs Grok AI chatbot. The investigation comes amid an outcry after users were able to prompt Grok to generate sexualized images of real people on X, including minors.

Microsoft announced the Maia 200, its latest chip designed for running AI models. The company said the chips are already running OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-5.2 models.

The U.S. Department of Transportation intends to use Gemini to draft new regulations, and has already used it to draft an unpublished rule for the Federal Aviation Administration, ProPublica reported.

Qwen released Qwen3-Max-Thinking, its latest reasoning model. According to test results that Qwen released, the model is comparable to leading models from OpenAI, Anthropic and Google.

Moonshot AI released a new open-source model, Kimi K2.5, which understands text, image and video.

Anthropic announced new features that will allow users to call up interactive apps like Slack, Canva and Figma within its Claude chatbot.

OpenAI released a report documenting how ChatGPT is being used in scientific research. According to the report, 1.3 million users per week ask ChatGPT about math and science.

A message from ServiceNow

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNow¬Æ works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more

By Valida Pau

item.title: My AI Had Already Fixed the Code Before I Saw It
item.description:
Compounding engineering turns every pull request, bug fix, and code review into permanent lessons your development tools apply automatically ¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå

Source Code

My AI Had Already Fixed the Code Before I Saw It

Compounding engineering turns every pull request, bug fix, and code review into permanent lessons your development tools apply automatically

by Kieran Klaassen

While we‚Äôre on our Think Week offsite this week, we‚Äôre resurfacing Cora general manager Kieran Klaassen‚Äôs work on the theme of compound engineering. In this piece, Kieran lays out his definition of the term and the shift it represents: What if your AI tools learned‚Äîand autonomously applied those lessons to future work? That‚Äôs what happened when his Claude Code agent incorporated three months of prior feedback without being asked. The future of development is self-improving systems, not just faster coding.‚ÄîKate Lee

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

Before I opened my laptop, the code had reviewed itself.

I launched GitHub expecting to dive into my usual routine‚Äîflag poorly named ÔªøvariablesÔªø, trim excessive tests, and suggest simpler ways to handle errors. Instead, I found a few strong comments from Claude Code, the AI that writes and edits in my terminal:

‚ÄúChanged variable naming to match pattern from PR [pull request] #234, removed excessive test coverage per feedback on PR #219, added error handling similar to approved approach in PR #241.‚Äù

In other words, Claude had learned from three prior months of code reviews and applied those lessons without being asked. It had picked up my tastes thoroughly, the way a sharp new teammate would‚Äîand with receipts.

It felt like cheating, but it wasn‚Äôt‚Äîit was compounding. Every time we fix something, the system learns. Every time we review something, the system learns. Every time we fail in an avoidable way, the system learns. That‚Äôs how we build Cora, Every‚Äôs AI-enabled email assistant, now: Create systems that create systems, then get out of the way.

I call this compounding engineering: building self-improving development systems where each iteration makes the next one faster, safer, and better.

Typical AI engineering is about short-term gains. You prompt, it codes, you ship. Then you start over. Compounding engineering is about building systems with memory, where every pull request teaches the system, every bug becomes a permanent lesson, and every code review updates the defaults. AI engineering makes you faster today. Compounding engineering makes you faster tomorrow, and each day after.

Three months of compounding engineering on Cora have completely changed the way I think about code. I can‚Äôt write a function anymore without thinking about whether I‚Äôm teaching the system or just solving today‚Äôs problem. Every bug fix feels half-done if it doesn‚Äôt prevent its entire category going forward, and code reviews without extractable lessons seem like wasted time.

When you‚Äôre done reading this, you‚Äôll have the same affliction.

Write at the speed of thought

That gap between your brain and your fingers kills momentum. Monologue lets you speak naturally and get perfect text 3x faster, and your tone, vocabulary, and style is kept intact. It auto-learns proper nouns, handles multilingual code-switching mid-sentence, and edits for accuracy. Free 1,000 words to start.

Download Monologue for Mac
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

The 10-minute investment that pays dividends forever

Compounding engineering asks for an upfront investment: You have to teach your tools before they can teach themselves.

Here‚Äôs an example of how this works in practice: I‚Äôm building a ‚Äúfrustration detector‚Äù for Cora; the goal is for our AI assistant to notice when users get annoyed with the app‚Äôs behavior and automatically file improvement reports. A traditional approach would be to write the detector, test it manually, tweak, and repeat. This takes significant expertise and time, a lot of which is spent context-switching between thinking like a user and thinking like a developer. It‚Äôd be better if the system could teach itself.

So I start with a sample conversation where I express frustration‚Äîlike repeatedly asking the same question with increasingly terse language. Then I hand it off to Claude with a simple prompt: ‚ÄúThis conversation shows frustration. Write a test that checks if our tool catches it.‚Äù

Claude writes the test. The test fails‚Äîthe natural first step in test-driven development (TDD). Next, I tell Claude to write the actual detection logic. Once written, it still doesn‚Äôt work perfectly, which is also to be expected. Now here‚Äôs the beautiful part: I can tell Claude to iterate on the frustration detection prompt until the test passes.

Not only that‚Äîit can keep iterating. Claude adjusts the prompt and runs the test again. It reads the logs, sees why it missed a frustration signal, and adjusts again. After a few rounds, the test passes.

But AI outputs aren‚Äôt deterministic‚Äîa prompt that works once might fail the next time.

So I have Claude run the test 10 times. When it only identifies frustration in four out of 10 passes, Claude analyzes why it failed the other six times. It studies the chain of thought (the step-by-step thinking Claude showed when deciding whether someone was frustrated) from each failed run and discovers a pattern: It‚Äôs missing hedged language a user might use, like, ‚ÄúHmm, not quite,‚Äù which actually signals frustration when paired with repeated requests. Claude then updates the original frustration-detection prompt to specifically look for this polite-but-frustrated language.

On the next iteration, it‚Äôs able to identify a frustrated user nine times out of 10. Good enough to ship.

We codify this entire workflow‚Äîfrom identifying frustration patterns to iterating prompts to validation‚Äîin CLAUDE.md, the special file Claude pulls in for context before each conversation. The next time we need to detect a user‚Äôs emotion or behavior, we don‚Äôt start from scratch. We say: ‚ÄúUse the prompt workflow from the frustration detector.‚Äù The system already knows what to do.

And unlike human-written code, the ‚Äúimplementation‚Äù here is a prompt that Claude can endlessly refine based on test results. Every failure teaches the system. Every success becomes a pattern. (We‚Äôre planning to open-source this prompt testing framework so other teams can build their own compounding workflows.)

From terminal to mission control

Most engineers treat AI as an extra set of hands. Compounding engineering turns it into an entire team that gets faster, sharper, and more aligned with every task.

At Cora, we‚Äôve used this approach to:

  1. Transform production errors into permanent fixes by having AI agents automatically investigate crashes, reproduce problems from system logs, and generate both the solution and tests to prevent it from happening again. This turns every failure into a one-time event.
  2. Extract architectural decisions from collaborative work sessions by recording design discussions with teammates, then having Claude document why certain approaches were chosen‚Äîcreating consistent standards that new team members inherit on day one.
  3. Build review agents with different expertise by capturing my own preferences in a ‚ÄúKieran reviewer‚Äù that enforces my style choices, then adding specialized perspectives like a ‚ÄúRails expert reviewer‚Äù for framework best practices or a ‚Äúperformance reviewer‚Äù for speed optimization.
  4. Automate visual documentation by deploying an agent that automatically detects interface changes, captures before/after screenshots across different screen sizes and themes, and generates comprehensive visual documentation‚Äîeliminating a 30-minute manual task while ensuring every interface change is properly documented for reviewers.
  5. Parallelize feedback resolution by creating a dedicated agent for each piece of reviewer feedback that works simultaneously to address concerns. This compresses a back-and-forth process that could take hours into parallel work where 10 issues get resolved in the time it used to take for one.

This way of working signifies a shift in what it means to be an engineer. Your job isn‚Äôt to type code anymore, but to design the systems that design the systems. It‚Äôs the only approach I‚Äôve found where today‚Äôs work makes tomorrow‚Äôs work exponentially easier, and where every improvement you make is permanent.

In the three months that we‚Äôve been running a compounding engineering workflow on Cora, our metrics have shifted noticeably. We‚Äôve seen time-to-ship on features drop from over a week to 1-3 days on average, and bugs caught before production have increased substantially. Pull request review cycles that used to drag on for days now finish in hours.

The compounding engineering playbook

Building systems that learn requires rewiring how you think about development. Even if you‚Äôre sold on compounding engineering, you might be wondering how to start. After months of refinement‚Äîand plenty of failed experiments‚ÄîI‚Äôve distilled it to five steps.

Step 1: Teach through work

Every time you make a decision, capture it and codify it to stop the AI from making the same mistake again. CLAUDE.md becomes your taste in plain language‚Äîwhy you prefer guard clauses over nested ifs or name things a certain way. Keep it short, keep it alive.

Likewise, the llms.txt file stores your high-level architectural decisions‚Äîthe design principles and system-wide rules that don‚Äôt change when you restructure individual features.

These files turn your preferences into permanent system knowledge that Claude applies automatically.


Step 2: Turn failures into upgrades

Something breaks? Good. That‚Äôs data. But here‚Äôs where most engineers stop: They fix the immediate issue and move on. Compounding engineers add the test, update the rule, and write the evaluation.

Take a recent example from Cora: A user reported that they never received their daily email Brief‚Äîa critical failure! We wrote tests that catch similar delivery lapses, updated our monitoring rules to flag when Briefs aren‚Äôt sent, and built evaluations that continuously verify the delivery pipeline.

Now the system always watches for this category of problem. What started as a failure has made our tools permanently smarter.

Step 3: Orchestrate in parallel

Unlike hiring engineers at $150,000 each, AI workers scale on demand. The only limits are your orchestration skills and compute costs‚Äînot headcount, hiring timelines, or team coordination overhead. You can spin up five specialized agents for the cost of a cup of coffee.

My monitor now looks like mission control:

  1. Left lane: Planning. A Claude instance reads issues, researches approaches, and writes detailed implementation plans.
  2. Middle lane: Delegating. Another Claude takes those plans and writes code, creates tests, and implements features.
  3. Right lane: Reviewing. A third Claude reviews the output against CLAUDE.md, suggests improvements, and catches issues.

It feels awkward at first‚Äîlike juggling while learning to juggle‚Äîbut within a week it becomes natural.


Step 4: Keep context lean but yours

The internet is full of ‚Äúultimate CLAUDE.md files‚Äù you can copy. Don‚Äôt. Your context should reflect your codebase, your patterns, and your hard-won lessons. Ten specific rules you follow beat 100 generic ones. And when rules stop serving you, delete them. Living context means pruning as much as growing.

When I review my CLAUDE.md/slash command and agent files, it feels like reading my own software philosophy‚Äîa reflection of what I‚Äôve learned, what I value, and how I think code should be built. If it doesn‚Äôt resonate with you personally, it won‚Äôt guide the AI effectively.

Step 5: Trust the process, verify output

This is the hardest step. Your instinct will be to micromanage and review every line. Instead, trust the system you‚Äôve built‚Äîbut verify through tests, evals, and spot checks. It‚Äôs like learning to be a CEO or a movie director: You can‚Äôt do everything yourself, but you can build systems that catch problems before they escalate. When something comes back wrong (and it will), teach the system why it was wrong. Next time, it won‚Äôt be.

Stop coding, start compounding

Here‚Äôs what I know: Companies are paying $400 per month for what used to cost $400,000 per year. One-person startups are competing with funded teams. AI is democratizing not just coding, but entire engineering systems. And leverage is shifting to those who teach these systems faster than they type.

Start with one experiment log today. When something fails that shouldn‚Äôt have, invest the time to prevent it from happening again‚Äîbuild the test, write the rule, and capture the lesson. Open three terminals. Try the three-lane setup: Plan in one, build in another, and review in a third. Say ‚Äúpull request‚Äù and watch the branches bloom.

Then do it again tomorrow, and see what compounds.

Thanks to Katie Parrott for editorial support.

Kieran Klaassen is the general manager of Cora, Every‚Äôs email product. Follow him on X at @kieranklaassen or on LinkedIn.

To read more essays like this, subscribe to Every, and follow us on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

We build AI tools for readers like you. Write brilliantly with Spiral. Organize files automatically with Sparkle. Deliver yourself from email with Cora. Dictate effortlessly with Monologue.

We also do AI training, adoption, and innovation for companies. Work with us to bring AI into your organization.

Get paid for sharing Every with your friends. Join our referral program.

For sponsorship opportunities, reach out to sponsorships@every.to.

Help us scale the only subscription you need to stay at the edge of AI. Explore open roles at Every.

Obvious Ventures lands fund five with a 360-degree view of planetary, human, economic health
