‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Obvious Ventures, co-founded by Twitter‚Äôs Evan Williams, has raised its fifth fund totaling $360,360,360, continuing its tradition of math-inspired fund numbers. The firm focuses on startups driving positive change in planetary health, human health, and economic health.
  • ‚Ä¢ Key investments include Zanskar, leveraging AI for geothermal energy to power AI data centers; Inceptive, an AI platform for molecule development founded by a pioneer of transformer architecture; and Dexterity Robotics, building humanoid robots for hazardous warehouse tasks.
  • ‚Ä¢ With notable successes like Beyond Meat, Planet Labs, and Recursion Pharmaceuticals, Obvious Ventures has established itself as a prominent VC player, aiming to make 10 investments annually in seed and Series A startups.
Node-based design tool Flora raises $42M from Redpoint Ventures
‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/27/node-based-design-tool-flora-raises-42m-from-redpoint-ventures/
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Flora, a design tool leveraging generative AI, enables users to create media assets like images and videos using text, image, or video inputs. Its node-based interface allows for iterative workflows, simplifying complex creative processes for designers and businesses alike.
  • ‚Ä¢ The startup secured $42 million in Series A funding led by Redpoint Ventures, with participation from notable investors including Vercel CEO Guillermo Rauch, Twitch founder Justin Kan, and a16z Games. Total funding now stands at $52 million.
  • ‚Ä¢ Flora plans to scale enterprise sales, enhance creative controls, and integrate traditional editing features, aiming to broaden its impact across industries like advertising, fashion, and branding while doubling or tripling its workforce by year-end.
Tech workers call for CEOs to speak up against ICE after the killing of Alex Pretti
‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/26/tech-workers-call-for-ceos-to-speak-up-against-ice-after-the-killing-of-alex-pretti/
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ The letter calls for tech firms to cancel contracts with ICE, highlighting significant partnerships like Palantir's $30M AI surveillance platform and cloud services provided by Amazon, Microsoft, and Oracle.
  • ‚Ä¢ Prominent tech leaders have spoken out against ICE actions, emphasizing the need to protect democratic values, while many top CEOs remain silent or maintain ties with the Trump administration.
Microsoft announces powerful new chip for AI inference
‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/26/microsoft-announces-powerful-new-chip-for-ai-inference/
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Maia 200 positions Microsoft as a competitor to Nvidia, Google, and Amazon in self-designed AI chips, offering 3x the FP4 performance of Amazon‚Äôs Trainium3 and surpassing Google‚Äôs seventh-generation TPU in FP8 performance.
  • ‚Ä¢ Already powering Microsoft‚Äôs AI models, including Copilot, Maia 200 is now accessible to developers, academics, and AI labs through its software development kit for advanced workloads.

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 27, 2026
Google AI Overviews cite YouTube more than any medical site for health queries
‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/jan/24/google-ai-overviews-youtube-medical-citations-study
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46766031
‚Ä¢ Score: 392
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion centers around Google‚Äôs AI system, Gemini, and its tendency to cite YouTube videos, including AI-generated content, as sources for its responses, particularly for health-related queries. Commenters debate the reliability and impact of this practice.
  • 2. **Key Themes**:
  • ‚Ä¢ **AI-generated content concerns**: Many commenters express distrust in AI-generated videos used as sources, citing their potential to spread misinformation and debase shared reality. The "closed loop" of AI citing AI content is viewed as problematic.
  • ‚Ä¢ **YouTube as a source**: Commenters are divided on whether citing YouTube is inherently bad. Some argue that it hosts valuable content from credible sources like hospitals and licensed professionals, while others criticize its lack of editorial oversight and prevalence of misinformation.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Reliability of AI responses**: Several commenters note inaccuracies and misleading information in Gemini‚Äôs responses, with some highlighting issues like vague citations and fabricated claims.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Health advice concerns**: There is skepticism about AI systems providing health-related advice, with concerns about the lack of tailored information and the prevalence of dubious recommendations from non-credible sources.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Corporate priorities**: Many commenters believe Google prioritizes engagement and ad revenue over the quality and reliability of its AI systems, citing conflicts of interest in favoring YouTube content.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ **Agreement**: Most commenters agree that AI systems should prioritize trustworthy, grounded sources and avoid reliance on AI-generated videos. There is widespread concern about the implications of misinformation and the degradation of shared reality.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Disagreement**: Some argue that YouTube can be a valid source if the videos are from credible organizations, while others believe YouTube‚Äôs general-purpose nature makes it unsuitable for medical or factual citations.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment is critical of Gemini and Google‚Äôs approach, with frustration over the perceived decline in quality and trustworthiness of AI systems. Some commenters express pessimism about the future of AI reliability, while others share nuanced perspectives on its potential benefits when used carefully.
  • 5. **Notable Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A few commenters suggest alternative tools like Kagi‚Äôs Research agent or specific platforms that anchor on peer-reviewed papers for better reliability.
  • ‚Ä¢ Personal anecdotes highlight both positive and negative experiences with AI systems in health contexts, showcasing their potential utility but also their risks.
  • ‚Ä¢ Commenters emphasize the need for rigorous source verification and transparency in AI-generated responses to mitigate misinformation.
  • ‚Ä¢ The concept of "citogenesis," where uncritical citation creates feedback loops of misinformation, is mentioned as a broader issue in AI systems.
  • 6. **Unique Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter shares a surprising instance where GPT3 provided accurate medical predictions, contrasting with Gemini‚Äôs perceived shortcomings.
  • ‚Ä¢ Others highlight systemic issues like the commercialization of search results and the lack of free access to high-quality medical journals, which may drive AI systems toward less reliable sources.
There is an AI code review bubble
‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.greptile.com/blog/ai-code-review-bubble
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46766961
‚Ä¢ Score: 301
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ The growing competition in AI code review tools highlights the importance of differentiation. Greptile emphasizes independence, refusing to integrate code generation features to ensure unbiased validation, likening it to separating auditors from bookkeepers.
  • ‚Ä¢ Greptile envisions a future of fully autonomous code validation, focusing on automating review, testing, and QA tasks to minimize human involvement. Unlike competitors, it avoids building user interfaces, positioning itself as a background automation solution.
  • ‚Ä¢ Feedback loops are central to Greptile‚Äôs approach, enabling iterative refinement between coding agents and validation agents until code meets high standards. Its Claude Code plugin exemplifies this by automating responses to review comments for seamless collaboration.

Discussion Highlights:

  • ‚Ä¢ **Main Topic:** The discussion centers around the effectiveness and challenges of AI tools for code review, including their strengths, weaknesses, and potential impact on software development workflows.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Signal-to-Noise Ratio:** A recurring theme is the poor signal-to-noise ratio in AI code review tools. Many commenters note that while AI tools often catch critical bugs, they also generate a large volume of irrelevant or low-value comments, which can overwhelm developers and lead to fatigue or dismissal of the feedback.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Comparison to Human Review:** Commenters generally agree that AI tools are not a replacement for human reviewers but can serve as useful complements. Human reviewers are better at understanding broader architectural and business contexts, mentoring team members, and making nuanced decisions about what is important. AI tools, on the other hand, excel at catching repetitive or low-level issues that humans might overlook.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Tool-Specific Experiences:**
  • ‚Ä¢ Tools like Copilot, Bugbot, and Claude Code received mixed reviews, with some users praising their ability to catch subtle bugs or suggest improvements, while others criticized their verbosity and lack of contextual understanding.
  • ‚Ä¢ Greptile was mentioned frequently, with some users finding it too noisy and prone to irrelevant suggestions, while others noted its potential to improve with better configuration or prompting.
  • ‚Ä¢ Coderabbit, Cursor, and Unblocked were highlighted as providing more focused and useful feedback compared to others.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Integration and Workflow:** Several commenters emphasized the importance of integrating AI tools seamlessly into existing workflows. Tools that are bundled with platforms like GitHub or GitLab were seen as having an advantage due to ease of use and lower integration costs. Some commenters expressed skepticism about the long-term viability of standalone AI code review tools, predicting that major platforms will eventually dominate this space.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Unique Insights:**
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters suggested that AI tools should focus on presenting fewer but higher-quality comments, potentially ranked by severity or importance, to reduce noise and improve developer experience.
  • ‚Ä¢ A few noted that AI tools could help with tasks like identifying race conditions, dead code, or overlooked edge cases, but their effectiveness diminishes for high-level design or business logic issues.
  • ‚Ä¢ There was discussion about the potential for AI tools to be misused or to create over-engineered code if developers blindly follow their suggestions.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Sentiment:** The overall sentiment of the discussion is mixed. While there is recognition of the potential value of AI code review tools, many commenters are critical of their current limitations, particularly around noise, lack of contextual understanding, and the risk of over-reliance on AI.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Broader Implications:** Commenters debated the future of AI code review, with some predicting that as AI improves, it could handle more aspects of the review process autonomously. Others expressed concerns about the potential loss of human understanding and the cultural aspects of code review, such as knowledge sharing and mentorship.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Critical Voices:** Some commenters questioned the fundamental premise of AI code review, arguing that it might be redundant or counterproductive when paired with AI-generated code. Others expressed frustration with the marketing and over-promising of certain tools, describing the current state of AI code review as part of a broader "AI bubble.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Conclusion:** While AI tools for code review are seen as promising, their current limitations, particularly in filtering out noise and understanding context, prevent them from fully replacing human reviewers. They are most effective when used as complementary tools to enhance, rather than replace, human judgment.
Porting 100k lines from TypeScript to Rust using Claude Code in a month
‚Ä¢ Article: https://blog.vjeux.com/2026/analysis/porting-100k-lines-from-typescript-to-rust-using-claude-code-in-a-month.html
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46765694
‚Ä¢ Score: 232
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ A developer successfully ported 100,000 lines of JavaScript code from the Pok√©mon Showdown project to Rust using Claude Code, an AI coding assistant, over four weeks, achieving a faster and more efficient implementation.
  • ‚Ä¢ The process required significant manual oversight, including sandbox workarounds, error resolution, and iterative cleanup, showcasing the potential and current limitations of AI-driven coding tools.
  • ‚Ä¢ Despite no prior Rust experience, the project resulted in a functional, optimized Rust codebase with 5,000 commits, highlighting the transformative potential of AI in software development while emphasizing the need for human expertise.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around the challenges and experiences of using AI tools, particularly Claude, to port code between programming languages, with a focus on Rust, JavaScript, and other environments. The broader theme includes the effectiveness, limitations, and quirks of AI in software engineering tasks.
  • 2. **Challenges with AI Porting**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Many commenters shared frustrations with Claude's tendency to introduce bugs or make unnecessary "improvements" during code porting, often leading to wasted time debugging issues.
  • ‚Ä¢ There were mentions of duplication and non-idiomatic code being generated, especially in Rust, which caused integration issues.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters noted that AI often struggles with tasks requiring deep understanding of the original code's constraints, resulting in suboptimal or broken outputs.
  • 3. **Strategies and Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Several participants suggested porting tests first and using them as a contract to ensure functionality during the porting process. Modular and progressive testing was highlighted as a key approach.
  • ‚Ä¢ File-by-file or class-by-class porting was recommended to maintain structure and avoid introducing unnecessary complexity.
  • ‚Ä¢ Using negative examples in prompts or leveraging plugins like code-review tools was proposed as a way to improve AI adherence to instructions.
  • 4. **Sentiment and Opinions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Mixed sentiment was evident. While some commenters appreciated the productivity gains and experimental nature of AI-driven porting, others were critical of the quality of the results and the significant babysitting required.
  • ‚Ä¢ Skepticism was expressed regarding the trustworthiness of AI-generated code, especially for critical or production-grade projects.
  • ‚Ä¢ A few comments outright dismissed certain projects as incomplete or disingenuous, questioning the utility of AI-generated codebases that merely compile without proper validation.
  • 5. **Unique Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Anecdotes of AI being used to port large codebases, such as a closed-source web conferencing tool or a low-level JS library, demonstrated potential use cases but also highlighted the need for human oversight.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters discussed the broader implications of AI tools in software development, such as using AI to port Python libraries to GIL-free versions or benchmarking ports across multiple languages.
  • ‚Ä¢ A humorous aside involved using AppleScript to auto-approve Claude's prompts, showcasing creative workarounds for AI quirks.
  • 6. **Cost and Usage Concerns**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The cost of running AI tools like Claude continuously was debated, with commenters sharing experiences about token limits and opaque subscription usage caps. API costs were noted as potentially higher than subscription models for heavy usage.
  • 7. **General Takeaways**:
  • ‚Ä¢ AI tools like Claude show promise in automating tedious tasks like code porting but are far from perfect and require significant human intervention to ensure quality.
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion highlighted the importance of robust testing, clear prompts, and understanding the limitations of AI when integrating it into software development workflows.
  • ‚Ä¢ While some commenters were optimistic about future advancements, others remained skeptical about AI's current capabilities, especially for complex or large-scale projects.
When AI 'builds a browser,' check the repo before believing the hype
‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/26/cursor_opinion/
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46769965
‚Ä¢ Score: 225
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Cursor claimed to have built a web browser using GPT-5.2, boasting 3 million lines of AI-generated code and a "from-scratch" Rust rendering engine, but the project was far from functional, with major compilation errors and reliance on existing tools like Servo and QuickJS.
  • ‚Ä¢ Developers found the browser's performance abysmal, with slow page loads and poorly designed code, leading to criticism from experts who described it as "spaghetti" and unsuitable for real-world use.
  • ‚Ä¢ The incident highlights the dangers of AI hype, as the experiment was marketed as a milestone rather than an internal learning exercise, emphasizing the need for validation and practical benchmarks over exaggerated claims.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion centered around the experiment of using AI to build a browser, which resulted in a codebase of over 3 million lines. Commenters debated its implications, effectiveness, and the broader narrative it promotes about AI capabilities.
  • ‚Ä¢ A recurring theme was skepticism about the value of "lines of code" (LOC) as a productivity metric, with many arguing that high LOC often indicates inefficiency or technical debt rather than progress.
  • ‚Ä¢ The hype surrounding AI's ability to produce complex software autonomously was critiqued, with commenters emphasizing the gap between AI demos and real-world production quality.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters discussed the broader implications of AI's role in software development, including its impact on management decisions and developer productivity.
  • 2. **Agreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Many commenters agreed that presenting the browser project as a success was misleading, as the resulting codebase was far from functional and relied heavily on external dependencies.
  • ‚Ä¢ There was consensus that LOC is a flawed metric for measuring software quality or developer productivity, with several commenters citing historical criticism of this approach.
  • ‚Ä¢ Commenters broadly acknowledged that AI tools can be useful for specific tasks, such as autocomplete or refactoring, but are not yet capable of handling complex projects without significant human intervention.
  • 3. **Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ While some viewed the experiment as a failure and a marketing stunt, others argued it demonstrated notable progress in AI's ability to tackle long, complex tasks, even if the outcome was imperfect.
  • ‚Ä¢ A few commenters defended AI coding tools as transformative for productivity in certain contexts, contrasting with the prevailing sentiment that the browser experiment was overhyped.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment was critical, with many commenters expressing frustration at the marketing and hype surrounding the project. There was concern about the unrealistic expectations being set for AI in software development.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters expressed cautious optimism about the future potential of AI, emphasizing that the experiment highlights progress despite its shortcomings.
  • 5. **Unique Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The analogy of "app-shaped objects" was used to describe AI-generated projects that superficially resemble functional software but fail under real-world conditions.
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter highlighted the economic consequences of AI hype, suggesting it leads to misguided management decisions and investor behavior.
  • ‚Ä¢ The concept of entropy in software development was discussed, with AI seen as contributing to technical debt rather than reducing it.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters proposed iterative approaches for AI-driven projects, starting with simpler tasks and gradually increasing complexity.
  • 6. **Key Takeaways**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The browser experiment showcased AI's ability to generate large amounts of code but failed to deliver a functional product, leading to skepticism about its practical value.
  • ‚Ä¢ Unrealistic claims about AI capabilities risk undermining trust and setting developers up for disappointment.
  • ‚Ä¢ AI tools are valuable for constrained tasks but are not yet capable of replacing human expertise in complex software projects.
  • ‚Ä¢ The hype cycle around AI continues to influence management and investment decisions, often to the detriment of developers and the industry at large.
Show HN: Only 1 LLM can fly a drone
‚Ä¢ Article: https://github.com/kxzk/snapbench
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46764170
‚Ä¢ Score: 169
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ A simulation inspired by Pok√©mon Snap tested 7 large language models (LLMs) on piloting a drone to identify creatures in a 3D voxel world. Surprisingly, the cheapest model, Gemini Flash, outperformed more expensive and advanced counterparts by successfully adjusting altitude to identify targets.
  • ‚Ä¢ The experiment revealed that spatial reasoning and instruction-following don‚Äôt necessarily scale with model size. Smaller models like Gemini Flash may excel due to different training data or simpler, more literal execution of commands.
  • ‚Ä¢ Future possibilities include model-specific tuning, richer feedback systems, extended iterations, and real-world drone benchmarks, potentially paving the way for more effective AI-driven navigation in physical and virtual spaces.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic and Context**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion revolves around the use of large language models (LLMs) for piloting drones and reasoning in 3D spaces. Commenters debated the feasibility, effectiveness, and limitations of using LLMs for tasks that involve spatial reasoning and real-time control.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • ‚Ä¢ **LLM Capabilities and Limitations**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Gemini 3 was highlighted as a model with some spatial reasoning abilities, though it is still unreliable for tasks like determining orientation (e.g., left vs. right). Other models like Qwen3VL were noted for their spatial grounding in pixel space but lacked reasoning capabilities.
  • ‚Ä¢ Several commenters pointed out that LLMs are not inherently designed for tasks like drone navigation or spatial reasoning, as they are primarily trained on text data. However, their ability to reason and generate commands makes them useful in specific contexts.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Challenges with Current Approaches**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Many commenters emphasized the brittleness of using a detection prepass followed by reasoning in text. This approach can lead to loss of important spatial and temporal data, resulting in errors such as state aliasing or compounded mistakes over time.
  • ‚Ä¢ LLMs were criticized for their unsuitability for real-time control tasks, with some suggesting traditional control systems (e.g., PID controllers) or gaming engines as better alternatives.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Use Cases and Applications**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters argued for the potential of LLMs in drone-related applications, such as responding to natural language commands, object identification, and autonomous decision-making. Examples included search-and-rescue missions, security drones, or waiter drones in restaurants.
  • ‚Ä¢ Others mentioned experiments with embodied LLMs and suggested that tighter feedback loops and dedicated training could improve their performance in such tasks.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Alternative Models and Tools**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Visual-language action (VLA) models were suggested as better suited for action-based tasks compared to general visual-language models (VLMs). Links to relevant projects like "Cognitive Drone" were shared.
  • ‚Ä¢ The idea of using LLMs to write programs for drone navigation, rather than directly controlling drones, was proposed as a potentially more effective approach.
  • 3. **Sentiment and Diverging Opinions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The sentiment was mixed. While some commenters were optimistic about the potential of LLMs for general reasoning and novel applications, others were skeptical of their practical use for drone control, citing their inherent limitations.
  • ‚Ä¢ There was a divide between those who saw LLM-based drone control as an exciting hacker project and those who viewed it as impractical or the wrong tool for the job.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter highlighted the importance of carrying forward uncertainty and temporal tracking from the vision stage to avoid compounded errors in reasoning.
  • ‚Ä¢ Another commenter pointed out that LLMs could complement traditional navigation models by handling ambiguous situations where reasoning is required, such as interpreting unexpected events.
  • ‚Ä¢ A few commenters raised concerns about the ethical implications of LLMs controlling drones, particularly in weaponized scenarios, referencing dystopian themes from popular media.
  • 5. **Conclusion**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion showcased a blend of technical analysis, practical concerns, and philosophical debates about the role of LLMs in embodied tasks. While LLMs have potential in certain contexts, their current limitations in spatial reasoning and real-time control make them less suitable for direct drone operation without significant augmentation or alternative approaches.
Suspiciously precise floats, or, how I got Claude's real limits
‚Ä¢ Article: https://she-llac.com/claude-limits
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46756742
‚Ä¢ Score: 59
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ A user discovered that Anthropic's Claude subscription plans unintentionally reveal exact usage limits through unrounded floats in the API, allowing for precise calculations of credit-token formulas and model multipliers.
  • ‚Ä¢ Using mathematical techniques like the Stern-Brocot tree and lowest common denominator analysis, the researcher uncovered the true usage limits by recovering fractions from floating-point numbers.
  • ‚Ä¢ This discovery highlights potential side-channel vulnerabilities in systems, as Anthropic's pricing details were inadvertently exposed due to overlooked rounding practices.

Discussion Highlights:

  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion revolves around methods for analyzing and converting repeating decimals into simpler forms or fractions.
  • ‚Ä¢ The initial comment by "zahlman" highlights an approach to simplify the repeating decimal 0.16327272727 by multiplying it by 11, resulting in a simpler value (1.796). The commenter appreciates the general analysis method but suggests a simpler approach for this specific case.
  • ‚Ä¢ A reply by "alyxya" explains a standard method for converting repeating decimals to fractions. They detail the process of dividing the repeating period by a sequence of 9s matching the length of the period, ultimately providing a fraction (449/2750) for the given decimal.
  • ‚Ä¢ Another reply by "PretzelPirate" asks whether the concept of multiplying by 11 is a named technique, showing interest in learning more about it.
  • ‚Ä¢ The tone of the discussion is analytical and curious, with commenters sharing methods and seeking additional knowledge. There are no significant disagreements, and the sentiment is constructive and collaborative.
OracleGPT: Thought Experiment on an AI Powered Executive
‚Ä¢ Article: https://senteguard.com/blog/#post-7fYcaQrAcfsldmSb7zVM
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46766507
‚Ä¢ Score: 57
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The use of AI and autonomous systems in decision-making roles, including algorithmic trading, autopilot systems, and the hypothetical idea of an "expert system" running a business or government functions.
  • ‚Ä¢ The feasibility and implications of AI systems being used for governance, such as implementing direct democracy or centralizing decision-making.
  • ‚Ä¢ Concerns about accountability when AI systems are given autonomy in management or policy-making roles.
  • ‚Ä¢ Criticism of current AI capabilities, particularly large language models (LLMs), and their limitations in handling complex or high-stakes tasks like legal briefs or policymaking.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Many commenters agree that AI systems are already being used in critical roles, such as trading and aviation, but question their broader application in management or governance.
  • ‚Ä¢ There is consensus that accountability is a significant barrier to fully autonomous AI decision-making, as AI cannot be held responsible in the same way humans can.
  • ‚Ä¢ Several commenters highlight the limitations of current AI systems, particularly LLMs, in reliably producing accurate or trustworthy outputs.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters are optimistic about the potential for AI to revolutionize governance (e.g., through direct democracy), while others are skeptical, citing risks of authoritarianism or manipulation by those in power.
  • ‚Ä¢ The practicality of using AI for management or governance is debated, with some seeing it as inevitable or beneficial and others viewing it as naive or fraught with challenges.
  • ‚Ä¢ There is disagreement on whether AI systems are more or less accountable than human managers, with some arguing that AI could simplify accountability (e.g., by being easily shut down) and others pointing out the ethical and legal complexities.
  • 4. **Notable Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter referenced the sci-fi work "Manna" as an example of an AI-run business, sparking debate on its realism and applicability to real-world scenarios.
  • ‚Ä¢ The idea of decentralized AI governance, where individual citizens control their own AI agents in a direct democracy setup, was proposed as an alternative to centralized systems.
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter mentioned an experimental project using historical political debates to train an AI model for capturing divergent views, highlighting potential academic interest in this area.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion reflects a mix of curiosity, skepticism, and cautious optimism. While some commenters are intrigued by the possibilities of AI in management and governance, many express concerns about accountability, ethical risks, and the current limitations of AI technology.
  • 6. **Unique Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The suggestion to decentralize AI governance by training individual agents per citizen was a particularly innovative idea.
  • ‚Ä¢ Historical context and references, such as the "Manna" sci-fi story and a GitHub project on AI and governance, added depth to the discussion.
  • ‚Ä¢ Humor and satire, such as the suggestion to make AI the CEO of Oracle, lightened the tone in parts of the conversation.
Is OpenAI Dead Yet?
‚Ä¢ Article: https://isopenaideadyet.com/
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46777448
‚Ä¢ Score: 53
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No, not yet. Still alive after 3,703 days... But getting there!

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The competitive landscape of AI development, particularly between the US and China, was a central topic. Commenters debated whether US AI models would maintain their lead or if Chinese models could catch up, with some pointing to China's historical ability to innovate and scale in other industries.
  • ‚Ä¢ OpenAI's current position and future prospects were discussed, with questions about its profitability, competition, and sustainability in a commoditized AI market.
  • ‚Ä¢ The difficulty of shorting OpenAI or gaining financial exposure to its success or failure was explored, with suggestions ranging from shorting associated companies to using prediction markets.
  • ‚Ä¢ Skepticism towards media narratives in AI, especially regarding exaggerated claims or negative rhetoric, was highlighted.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • ‚Ä¢ There was general acknowledgment of the competitive pressures in the AI space and the challenges faced by OpenAI and other companies in maintaining leadership.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters agreed that Chinese companies face similar issues to US companies in scaling and sustaining AI operations.
  • ‚Ä¢ The media's tendency to sensationalize or misrepresent developments in AI was a shared concern.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Opinions varied on whether Chinese AI models are genuinely behind US models or if they are closing the gap. Some commenters argued that China has proven its ability to innovate, while others expressed skepticism about its ability to surpass the US.
  • ‚Ä¢ There was debate over the feasibility and effectiveness of shorting OpenAI-related investments, with some suggesting it is a risky or impractical strategy.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ One commenter pointed out that OpenAI's potential collapse could impact the share prices of publicly traded companies with ties to AI, such as Microsoft, Oracle, and SoftBank.
  • ‚Ä¢ The fragmented nature of AI development across different regions (US, China, Europe) was noted as a likely outcome, with each region potentially developing its own models to avoid reliance on foreign technology.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The sentiment was mixed, with a blend of cautious optimism about AI's future and skepticism about specific companies' sustainability and the media's portrayal of the industry. While some commenters expressed confidence in the US maintaining its AI lead, others were more critical of assuming long-term dominance.
  • 6. **Notable Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A detailed comment highlighted China's historical trajectory in innovation and manufacturing, arguing that dismissing its AI potential could be shortsighted.
  • ‚Ä¢ Links to external resources, such as prediction markets and investment fund details, added depth to the financial discussion around OpenAI.
  • Overall, the discussion reflected a nuanced and critical examination of AI's competitive dynamics, OpenAI's trajectory, and the broader implications for the industry.
Georgia leads push to ban datacenters used to power America's AI boom
‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/jan/26/georgia-datacenters-ai-ban
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46767696
‚Ä¢ Score: 52
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion revolves around the regulation and impact of data centers, with a focus on energy consumption, environmental concerns, and local community effects.
  • ‚Ä¢ One commenter proposed alternative regulations for data centers instead of outright bans, such as requiring zero water usage, zero emissions, limits on noise levels, zoning restrictions, and energy usage caps.
  • ‚Ä¢ Several commenters debated the rationale behind banning data centers:
  • ‚Ä¢ One commenter argued that the focus should be on increasing electricity generation capacity rather than banning data centers.
  • ‚Ä¢ Another highlighted the issue of utilities scaling up power capacity to meet anticipated demand from data centers, only for the data centers to reduce their needs or abandon plans, leaving local ratepayers burdened with the costs.
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter shared a personal perspective on living near a data center, describing increased electricity costs, pollution, and a negative impact on quality of life.
  • ‚Ä¢ Environmental and resource concerns were emphasized:
  • ‚Ä¢ One commenter noted the rapid proliferation of data centers compared to the slower pace of building power plants, suggesting a mismatch in infrastructure development.
  • ‚Ä¢ Another humorously criticized the prioritization of data storage over basic needs like clean air and water.
  • ‚Ä¢ A separate thread briefly touched on AI regulation and its connection to data centers:
  • ‚Ä¢ One commenter claimed it is federally illegal to regulate AI, but others refuted this, citing the rejection of a proposed moratorium on state AI regulation and clarifying that current discussions focus on data centers and energy, not AI itself.
  • ‚Ä¢ It was also pointed out that executive orders do not override local land use decisions or moratoriums on data center siting.
  • ‚Ä¢ Overall, the sentiment of the discussion is mixed, with some commenters advocating for more thoughtful regulation of data centers and others expressing frustration over their local and environmental impacts. The conversation also reflects broader concerns about balancing technological progress with resource management and community well-being.

auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>In 2011, Palantir did something funny. They took their solutions engineers and integration engineers—typically among the lower-status roles in any engineering org—and gave them a new title: </span><em>forward-deployed engineer</em><span>. They even called them “Deltas,” like Delta Force. It sounded ridiculous, and it worked brilliantly.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>It seems like Palantir understood two things. First, they understood that these employees were undervalued: they were critical to customer success and business reputation, but traditionally treated as replaceable help. Second, they understood something about titles, which we’ll call </span><em>title arbitrage</em><span>: the fact that </span><strong>titles can be an effective way of meme-ing into existence the change you want to see in the world.</strong></p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 style="text-decoration: none;">Subscribed</span></a></div></div></div></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">What is title arbitrage?</h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Title arbitrage means creating new roles to signify new powers that are emerging within the organization, and therefore, new capabilities of the organization itself.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Like it or not, a lot of professional life is judging people by their titles. The CEO is probably the most important person in the room, and the COO, CTO or CFO is probably the second-most (depending on the company). Titles are useful. They tell us something about the work product of the person: the Vice President of Manufacturing is, well, the guy in charge of manufacturing. Titles confer legitimacy.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Titles are also about </span><em>legible organizational capacity</em><span>. Companies are these weird things where many people get together to take actions in coordinated ways that add up to be much more than what any individual person could do. And in order for that coordination to be effective, you need a shared agreement over what roles speak to what organizational capacities.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>But here’s the thing about organizational capacity: it </span><em>changes</em><span>. The world changes, and different skills and competencies become more useful or less useful. In 1770, cavalry officers needed to be able to ride horses; but by 1970, the “cavalry” meant helicopters. So the distribution of power, of </span><em>leverage</em><span>, shifts. And eventually titles, which are supposed to signify power, have to shift with them.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">And the people who figure this out earlier than others, the ones who know where the wind is blowing, can reap enormous benefits.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">By recasting the role, like Walmart did with “Greeter” or Disney with “Imagineer”, Palantir effectively bet: “deep software integrations with huge enterprises and governments will be really important in the future. This work needs to have its profile raised accordingly.” And they were right. The FDE role attracted high-agency, high-EQ engineers who might otherwise have seen client-facing work as unappreciated. The title gave the work prestige—and Palantir got a hiring moat.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">Some examples</h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Once you start to look, you see title arbitrage everywhere.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="976" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/a58cc171-f4c0-4792-9aac-a10deb31f26f?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" data-attrs="{"src":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/1c41a5d6-bd90-4f02-ad96-9a62f18b8564_976x550.png","srcNoWatermark":null,"fullscreen":null,"imageSize":null,"height":550,"width":976,"resizeWidth":null,"bytes":null,"alt":null,"title":null,"type":null,"href":null,"belowTheFold":true,"topImage":false,"internalRedirect":null,"isProcessing":false,"align":null,"offset":false}" alt="" width="550" height="309.9385245901639" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!u1sF!,w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F1c41a5d6-bd90-4f02-ad96-9a62f18b8564_976x550.png" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>There’s no better example than with the people who make every technical company run—coders. First, coders were relatively unimportant, and they were called “IT.” But IT conjures up cubicles, </span><em>Dilbert</em><span>, </span><em>Office Space</em><span>. But as software grew in business importance, the names of roles changed to become “programmers,” which is a bit cooler, but still had a sort of nerdy vibe. And then in the 2000s/2010s, once software truly started to eat the world, coders became “software engineers”! They’re big thinkers, not just code monkeys, but engineers building transformative technology like the people who build bridges and airplanes. The names of these roles continually changed as the status of the work they were doing rose in business importance.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">In the world of data, the progression went from “clerk” to “data entry” to “data scientist” to, now, “machine learning engineer”—each shift tracking the rising strategic value of being the person who works with data. It used to be a low-status job; now it’s one of the most important roles in any serious org. The same with the lowly system administrator: Google coined the term “Site Reliability Engineer” to signal that keeping systems running was as intellectually demanding as building them in the first place.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The same thing happened with marketing. Dropbox, Facebook and others made “growth hacker” and then “Head of Growth” legitimate titles, signaling that marketing had become a part of the product org: engineering-adjacent and experiment-driven. “Social media manager” evolved into “Head of Community” or “Head of Ecosystem”—managing a Twitter account became owning the relationship with an entire ecosystem.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">In design, “graphic designer” became “UX designer” became “product designer” became “design engineer”—each step capturing more ownership over the end product. In operations, “secretary” became “executive assistant” became “chief of staff” or “head of ops”—a deliberately ambiguous title, sitting somewhere between scheduling meetings and shaping strategy.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">New titles can signal business model shifts</h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">What Clay is doing now with “GTM engineer”, or what Harvey is doing with “legal engineer” goes genuinely beyond just marketing; it describes work that genuinely didn’t exist five years ago.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>But here’s the question skeptics will ask: isn’t this just status inflation? What differentiates this genuine phenomenon compared to title </span><em>inflation</em><span> - where titles run a Red Queen’s Race of escalating fake prestige, simply to keep in place within a labor market where inflation is commonplace? Or more opaque resumé padding, where insiders confer elaborate titles on each other to appear opaquely impressive to outsiders? (Like “Lead Editor” in a law journal, which can counterintuitively mean the most junior contributor?)</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The difference is whether there’s a </span><em>real, underlying shift in the work</em><span>. “Prompt engineer,” which Scale AI pioneered, already feels dated, because the work it described—writing prompts—turned out to be a feature of every job rather than a job unto itself. The title ran ahead of reality. But “GTM engineer” or “legal engineer” describe genuinely new combinations of skills that companies actually need.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The test is this: does the new title describe work that would have been unrecognizable five years ago? If yes, you might be onto something. If you’re just renaming “marketing coordinator” to “growth strategist,” but keeping all the responsibilities the same, then you’re not doing title arbitrage: you’re doing title inflation, and the best people will be able to tell the difference.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">And we’re now seeing the emergence of titles in other industries caught in AI transformation. Watch for more of these in the coming years: “prompt engineer” evolving into “AI applications engineer” or “model behavior specialist.” “Compliance officer” becoming “AI governance lead.” “Analyst” in consulting and finance becoming “intelligence engineer” for those building AI-augmented research workflows.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="1456" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/86aba419-5ef4-41f8-83c1-af6ab0d44e8f?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" data-attrs="{"src":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/b9d23abf-ef0a-4421-8606-df8eb97591b3_2000x1672.png","srcNoWatermark":null,"fullscreen":null,"imageSize":null,"height":1217,"width":1456,"resizeWidth":null,"bytes":164474,"alt":null,"title":null,"type":"image/png","href":null,"belowTheFold":true,"topImage":false,"internalRedirect":"https://www.a16z.news/i/185887993?img=https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fb9d23abf-ef0a-4421-8606-df8eb97591b3_2000x1672.png","isProcessing":false,"align":null,"offset":false}" alt="" width="550" height="459.7184065934066" auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table><figcaption class="image-caption" style="box-sizing: content-box;color: rgb(119,119,119);font-size: 14px;line-height: 20px;font-weight: 400;letter-spacing: -.15px;margin-top: 8px;width: 70%;padding-left: 15%;padding-right: 15%;text-align: center;"><em>These are from Google Trends, so take it with a grain of salt, but what really stands out here is the recent surge for “Legal Engineer.” Harvey’s really been pulling the SEO lever, it seems!</em></figcaption></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The main utility of this for the company is also that it signals to other companies, “you should care what this person says.” A name is a pointer. It points to something you should care about. A new name gives people permission to care about this new thing.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Early adopting lawyers, afraid of AI, can now self-identify as legal engineers. Lawyers know a lot about contract redlines and mitigating risk, but not much about workflow automation or context graphs. But legal engineers know both. The new title gives early-adopting legal professionals permission to learn to use AI from a place of empowerment, instead of fear.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><em>People</em><span> transform companies, more than products do</span></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>This points to something important about how AI actually transforms organizations. When you look at a regular company and ask “how is AI going to change this business,” the stock answer is “all of these interfaces are going to get smarter,” or “</span><em>x</em><span> tools are going to change.” But that’s also the </span><em>wrong</em><span> answer. The much better answer is this: specific people, often young people, are going to use AI to have dramatically more leverage to solve problems inside the org, and you are going to be </span><em>shocked</em><span> by how effective they are. The imperative for every CEO or org leader is this: </span><em>identify them, listen to them, and promote them</em><span>.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">There’s a classic pattern in large companies whenever they adopt groundbreaking new software, like when Airbus adopts Palantir. All the smart young people come out of the woodwork and use the new software to improve things. New technology shifts the balance of power in the organization, and it’s always the ambitious young people who realize this first. This is where new titles can be a genuine indicator of people creating new jobs for themselves out of newfound leverage.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">And a newly named job title has incredibly strong PMF for these kinds of people. It bestows social legitimacy on what they’re doing. “Oh, great, Alex, you love this tool—why don’t you be our legal engineer”?</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>And if your company is an early mover on this, you hold the power—and if you’re the first mover, </span><em>you own it</em><span>: you define the entire job.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Today, there are hundreds of companies hiring FDEs. But Palantir </span><em>owns</em><span> FDE. Any time you think of the FDE term, you think of Palantir. Because they moved first to own this term, they have incredible mindshare when it comes to hiring. When a talented engineer considers client-facing technical work, Palantir is the default comparison—not because they’re necessarily the best place to do the job, but because they </span><em>named</em><span> the job.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">So if AI is transforming your industry, work out what the jobs of the future will be. Coin a new title. Plant a flag. Winning attention is one of the hardest challenges for businesses today. If your market associates a winning concept with your company, you are much closer to winning yourself.</p><div class="subscribe-widget is-signed-up is-fully-subscribed" item.title: ‚òïü§ñTutorial: Close Clients 2x Faster With AI (Proposal Engine)
item.description:
<html style="scrollbar-width: thin;scrollbar-color: rgb(219,219,219)rgb(255,255,255);"><head><meta charset="utf-8"><title>☕🤖Tutorial: Close Clients 2x Faster With AI (Proposal Engine)</title><style>
@media (max-width: 1024px) {
  .typography .pullquote-align-left,
  .typography.editor .pullquote-align-left,
  .typography .pullquote-align-right,
  .typography.editor .pullquote-align-right,
  .typography .pullquote-align-wide,
  .typography.editor .pullquote-align-wide,
  .typography .pullquote-align-center,
  .typography.editor .pullquote-align-center {
    float: none;
    margin: 0 auto;
    width: 100%;
    max-width: 100%;
  }
}
@media all and (-ms-high-contrast: none), (-ms-high-contrast: active) {
  .typography .markup table.image-wrapper img,
  .typography.editor .markup table.image-wrapper img,
  .typography .markup table.kindle-wrapper img,
  .typography.editor .markup table.kindle-wrapper img {
    max-width: 550px;
  }
}
@media (min-width: 1024px) {
  .typography:not(:has(#toc)) .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-left),
  .typography.editor:not(:has(#toc)) .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-left) {
    margin-left: var(--image-offset-margin);
  }
  .typography:not(:has(#toc)) .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-right),
  .typography.editor:not(:has(#toc)) .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-right) {
    margin-right: var(--image-offset-margin);
  }
}
@media (min-width: 1300px) {
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-left),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-left) {
    margin-left: var(--image-offset-margin);
  }
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-right),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-right) {
    margin-right: var(--image-offset-margin);
  }
}
@media (max-width: 1024px) {
  .typography,
  .typography.editor {
    /* Disable offset on mobile/tablet */
  }
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-left),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-left),
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-right),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-right) {
    float: none;
    margin: 1em auto;
    max-width: 100%;
    width: auto;
    padding: 0;
  }
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-left.thefp),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-left.thefp),
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-right.thefp),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-right.thefp) {
    margin: 1em auto;
  }
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-left),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-left),
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-right),
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-offset-right) {
    margin: 1em auto;
  }
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-left) .image2-inset,
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-left) .image2-inset,
  .typography .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-right) .image2-inset,
  .typography.editor .captioned-image-container figure:has(> a.image2-align-right) .image2-inset {
    display: block;
    justify-content: initial;
  }
}
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .typography .markup div.sponsorship-campaign-embed,
  .typography.editor .markup div.sponsorship-campaign-embed {
    margin-top: 24px;
    margin-bottom: 24px;
  }
  .typography .markup div.sponsorship-campaign-embed:first-child,
  .typography.editor .markup div.sponsorship-campaign-embed:first-child {
    margin-top: 0px;
  }
}
@media screen and (max-width: 650px) {
  .typography .markup div.youtube-overlay,
  .typography.editor .markup div.youtube-overlay,
  .typography .markup div.vimeo-overlay,
  .typography.editor .markup div.vimeo-overlay {
    display: none !important;
  }
}

  .typography .markup div.captioned-button-wrap .subscription-widget.show-subscribe .subscription-widget-subscribe .button,
  .typography.editor .markup div.captioned-button-wrap .subscription-widget.show-subscribe .subscription-widget-subscribe .button {

  }
}
@media (max-width: 650px) {
  .typography .markup .twitter-embed,

  .typography.editor .markup .tweet {

  .typography .markup .twitter-embed .tweet-text,

  .typography .markup .tweet .tweet-text,

}
@media (max-width: 650px) {

  .typography .markup .tweet .tweet-photos-container.two,
  .typography.editor .markup .tweet .tweet-photos-container.two,

  .typography.editor .markup .twitter-embed .tweet-photos-container.three,
  .typography .markup .tweet .tweet-photos-container.three,
  .typography.editor .markup .tweet .tweet-photos-container.three,

  .typography .markup .tweet .tweet-photos-container.four,
  .typography.editor .markup .tweet .tweet-photos-container.four {
    height: 200px;
  }
}
@media (max-width: 650px) {
  .typography .markup .twitter-embed a.expanded-link .expanded-link-img,
  .typography.editor .markup .twitter-embed a.expanded-link .expanded-link-img,
  .typography .markup .tweet a.expanded-link .expanded-link-img,
  .typography.editor .markup .tweet a.expanded-link .expanded-link-img {
    max-height: 180px;
  }
}
@media (max-width: 650px) {
  .typography .markup .twitter-embed a.expanded-link .expanded-link-description,
  .typography.editor .markup .twitter-embed a.expanded-link .expanded-link-description,
  .typography .markup .tweet a.expanded-link .expanded-link-description,
  .typography.editor .markup .tweet a.expanded-link .expanded-link-description {

  }
}
@media screen and (max-width: 650px) {
  .typography .markup .apple-podcast-container,
  .typography.editor .markup .apple-podcast-container {
    width: unset;
  }
}
@media (max-width: 420px) {
  .typography .markup .install-substack-app-embed img.install-substack-app-embed-img,
  .typography.editor .markup .install-substack-app-embed img.install-substack-app-embed-img {

}
@media (max-width: 420px) {

1.375em;"><strong>🌟 The Goal</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">By the end of this, you’ll be able to:</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>✅ Turn any discovery call into a proposal in 15–30 minutes</span><br><span>✅ Make every proposal feel custom, not templated</span><br><span>✅ Add stronger positioning and proof without extra work</span><br><span>✅ Reduce back-and-forth with clearer scope + deliverables</span><br><span>✅ Increase close rate with a better “decision path”</span></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>🧠 What Great Proposals Actually Do</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">A proposal isn’t a document.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>It’s a </span><em>decision device</em><span>.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The best proposals do 5 things:</p><ol style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Re-state the client’s situation better than they can</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Diagnose the real bottleneck (not symptoms)</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Present a simple plan with milestones</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Define scope so there’s no confusion later</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Make the next step feel obvious and low friction</p></li></ol><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">We’ll build that as a repeatable system using prompts 👇</p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>🚀 Prompt #1 - The Client Diagnosis (turn chaos into clarity)</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Before you pitch a plan, you need to </span><strong>prove you understand the problem</strong><span>.</span></p><blockquote style="border-left: 4px solid #5365d0;margin: 20px 0;padding: 0;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em><span>This is where most proposals fail:</span><br><span>They jump straight to deliverables without showing insight.</span></em></p></blockquote><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Use this prompt right after a discovery call or when a client sends a messy email. It will turn raw notes into a clean “what’s happening + why” diagnosis.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em><strong>Prompt:</strong></em></p><pre style="position: relative;background: rgb(238,238,238);padding: 16px;margin: 32px 0;border-radius: 8px;box-sizing: border-box;"><code style="white-space: pre-wrap;font-size: 16px;line-height: 20px;font-weight: 500;">You are a senior consultant who turns discovery notes into clear client diagnosis.

Context:
Client name: [Client]
Industry: [Industry]
Goal: [What they want]
Constraints: [budget, timeline, team, tools]

Here are my discovery notes / transcript:
[Paste notes]

Deliver:
- Executive summary (2–4 sentences)
- Current situation (what’s happening now)
- Key challenges (ranked)
- Root cause diagnosis (what’s actually causing the issues)
- Opportunities (quick wins + strategic wins)
- Success metrics (what we will measure)

Make it clear, specific, and written like a real consultant. No buzzwords.</code></pre><blockquote style="border-left: 4px solid #5365d0;margin: 20px 0;padding: 0;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">💡 Tip: If you don’t have notes, paste the client’s website + a short summary of what you observed.</p></blockquote><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>🧭 Prompt #2 - The Strategy Blueprint (plan that feels premium)</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Now that you have the diagnosis, you need a plan that feels:</p><ul style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">structured</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">realistic</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">measurable</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">easy to say yes to</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">This prompt creates a strategy section that reads like a $10K proposal without being bloated.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em><strong>Prompt:</strong></em></p><pre style="position: relative;background: rgb(238,238,238);padding: 16px;margin: 32px 0;border-radius: 8px;box-sizing: border-box;"><code style="white-space: pre-wrap;font-size: 16px;line-height: 20px;font-weight: 500;"><span>Act as a senior strategist.

Using this diagnosis:
</span><strong>[Paste output from Prompt #1]</strong><span>

Create a proposal-ready strategy plan.

</span><strong>Include:</strong><span>

- Objective (1 sentence)
- Strategy pillars (3–5 max)
- For each pillar:
--- what we’ll do
--- why it matters
--- expected impact

- Timeline overview (Week 1–4 or Month 1–3)
- Assumptions (what must be true for this to work)

Make it concise and specific. Write like you’re presenting to a founder who wants clarity.</span></code></pre><blockquote style="border-left: 4px solid #5365d0;margin: 20px 0;padding: 0;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">🧠 Tip: Ask it to include “what we’re NOT doing” to increase trust and reduce scope creep.</p></blockquote><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">A huge reason proposals create problems later is vague scope.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">You need deliverables that are:</p><ul style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">clear</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">measurable</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">and hard to misunderstand</p></li></ul><blockquote style="border-left: 4px solid #5365d0;margin: 20px 0;padding: 0;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">This prompt turns strategy
